18 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 mai 2017
Développé par Act 3 Games, LLC où travaille le directeur artistique de God of War III, The Fidelio Incident est un jeu d'aventure à mi-chemin entre Firewatch et Kholat. On y incarne Stanley, un homme en fuite avec sa compagne Leonore qui va s'écraser en avion en Islande. Séparés l'un de l'autre, il va devoir essayer de la retrouver avant qu'elle ne meure d'hypothermie. Dans ses recherches, il va également devoir trouver et récupérer leurs traces prenant la formes de notes et du journal intime de Leonore. Vous l'avez bien compris, on est en plein Walking simulator inspiré de Dear Esther et autres mais aussi de l'opéra de Beethoven Fidelio.

The Fidelio Incident est basé sur le moteur Unreal Engine 4 ce qui le rend déjà plutôt agréable à regarder et à jouer. Le jeu se joue à la première personne et il va falloir aller chercher des notes et résoudre des puzzles plus ou moins complexes pour avancer et découvrir ce qui est réellement arrivé à nos protagonistes et pourquoi ils sont en fuite. C'est en allant explorer en dehors des sentiers battus que l'on découvrira la réelle complexité de l'histoire et sur son côté très émotionnel. On est pas vraiment face à un simulateur de survie à l'instar du fabuleux The Long Dark, on peut mourir de froid mais c'est assez limité, il faut juste suivre les feux environnants et les conduits de vapeur afin de se réchauffer immédiatement. Le jeu est intégralement en anglais avec de très bons acteurs qui rendent le couple et l'histoire fort prenante malgré une certaine disparité entre les faits impliquant nos protagonistes en Irlande et ce qui leur arrive en Islande.

The not so Long Dark.
The Fidelio Incident est un jeu plutôt sympathique avec de réelles bonnes idées et une réalisation de haute volée. On est assez impressionné devant le spectacle proposé par le jeu et par le jeu des acteurs. Ce n'est qu'au bout de quelques minutes que l'on va réellement comprendre ce qui manque au jeu, une réelle cohérence dans sa thématique par rapport à son gameplay. En effet, on enchaine des phases de recherche de notes et des phases de puzzles simplistes et impliquant des valves et autres interrupteurs à actionner. C'est extrêmement limité et l'intérêt de ces phases se heurte rapidement à une certaine lassitude au bout d'une heure. On active une valve, on se déplace pour aller trouver une autre valve et on l'actionne pour passer à la suite. Parfois, il faudra trouver un objet nous permettant d'avancer mais tout est fortement linéaire et trop simple à trouver.

Sans réellement forcer, on arrivera à la fin du jeu au bout de 2-3 heures avec la quasi intégralité des achievements. Il ne m'en manquait qu'un seule à la fin de ma première partie. N'espérez donc pas un jeu qui vous tiendra en haleine 5-6 heures durant. Après c'est n'est pas forcément un défaut lorsque le jeu parvient à nous prendre dans son ambiance et dans la ritournelle des émotions qu'il procure. The Fidelio Incident est certes basé sur une interprétation très libre d'un opéra mais sa réelle histoire ne m'a pas fondamentalement bouleversé avec ses relents d'IRA et ses actions terroristes. Certaines scènes sont d'ailleurs trop dirigistes pour procurer l'émotion qu'elles veulent nous instiller, du coup on se contente d'avancer tel un robot en laissant appuyer sur la touche de Sprint en attendant que cela se termine pour pouvoir avancer.

It's not me, mate, you've got the wrong guy.
Le jeu est vraiment magnifique, on est parfois impressionné devant l'immensité des décors mais aussi devant leur diversité. Plus tard dans le jeu, on pourra découvrir certains éléments un peu hors de propos si l'on considère la cadre de départ et surtout certaines métaphores plutôt douteuses notamment lors de la tentative de sauvetage de Leonore. On passe toutefois un agréable moment avec une musique disponible gratuitement sous forme de DLC et quelques bons moments dans la glace et au niveau du lac gelé. Il y a énormément de bonnes intentions dans The Fidelio Incident mais le mélange final de ces différents types de gameplay sonne un peu creux. Pas assez action pour satisfaire les amateurs d'exploration et pas assez impliquant pour les amoureux des walking simulators émotionnels.

Le jeu n'est pas bien cher et il est sorti dans un certain anonymat sans strasses et paillettes ce qui n'est pas si fréquent sur Steam. Sans être un mauvais jeu, The Fidelio Incident est une expérience singulière qui tente l'approche prise par Firewatch mais sans convaincre avec la même force. J'ai passé un agréable moment mis à part la toute fin que j'ai trouvé assez prévisible et pas forcément bien amenée. Je ne regrette pas du tout d'avoir acheté le jeu à sa sortie mais je vous conseille toutefois d'attendre un peu pour peu que vous aimiez le genre et qu'un voyage en Islande vous intéresse à tout petit prix. Notre voyagiste n'est certes pas Voyageurs du monde mais le dépaysement est total malgré quelques grossières fautes de gout qui ternisse le tableau au final. Dommage.
 
Loutre Perfide

Recommandé
2.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 aout 2018
Je savais plus ou moins à quoi m'attendre avec The Fidelio Incident: Un simulateur de marche comme Dear Esther, de beaux décors, blablabla.

Mais The Fidelio Incident est bien plus que ça.

The Fidelio Incident 
Une capture d'écran de The Fidelio Incident
Par : Mokato


The Fidelio Incident est un poème vivant, l'histoire d'un amour perdu que l'on doit sauver, un chemin vers la rédemption, une triste catastrophe.

The Fidelio Incident nous emmène dans des contrées glaciales, d'une beauté sans nom, dans un monde à la foi déj) vu mais pourtant inconnu et plein de mystères.

The Fidelio Incident 
Une capture d'écran de The Fidelio Incident
Par : Mokato


Je ne saurais faire une évaluation normale de ce jeu, cela enlèverait toute sa surprise et sa beauté.
C'est un jeu avec des graphismes très jolis et une histoire poignante et des petits puzzles sympathiques.

Si vous avez aimé Dear Esther ou The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, foncez, le jeu est souvent bradé à moins de 1€.

Recommandé
2.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 janvier 2019
T'aimes les films interactifs ? Les jeux "Simulateur de marche" ?T'as aimé Dear Esther ?
Ce jeu est fait pour toi !
Il est encore plus beau que ce dernier, la voice acting est SU-PER (et ces accents... <3) et pour couronner le tout, il y a de l'action, des rebondissements et tout ce que tu veux pour faire un bon film.
(bon, dès le crash, le premier truc que dit la copine , je me suis douté d'un truc, mais bref...)

On ne s'ennuit jamais (a par peut être si t'aimes pas les enigmes, il y en a 3/4 sur 2h environ, mais elles sont franchement pas compliquées).

Le seul bémol, c'est si tu comprends rien à l'anglais, t'es dans la mierde, car tout est en anglais jusqu'au sous titres.
(Ca ne me dérange pas, mais faut quand même le souligner, ça pourrait en rebuter pas mal)

A noté aussi qu'on a la possibilité de courrir dans le jeu ! Chose assez importante je trouve, car avoir l'impression de jouer un tracteur dans un jeu, c'est pas agréable DU TOUT !

Et de plus, attendez de le trouver soldé, il l'est souvent et a moins de 2€, et il les vaut largement !
 
Melandria
1,886 produits enregistrés
0
10 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 novembre 2017
The Fidelio Incident est un simulateur de marche qui tire son nom du seul opera qu'ait produit Beethov'. Ouais, ça fait genre je-sais-de-quoi-je-parle. Même si, pour être tout à fait honnête, je dois bien avouer ne jamais l'avoir vu. Il reprend donc de cet opéra divers éléments, à commencer par Leonore, le nom que porte la femme du personnage principal. Lequel s'appelle Stanley. Enchanté. Il intègre aussi des pans de son histoire, notamment le passage sur la prison, et une partie de sa musique. Du coup, inutile de vous dire que la bande son est du meilleur effet !

Toujours dans la catégorie audio, mention particulière pour le doublage, d'excellente facture. Non contents d'être tout à fait crédibles, l'un de ces personnages (tous deux censés être irlandais) est doublé par Glenn Keogh, lui-même natif du pays de la Guiness ; Stanley, en l'occurence. Et non, je ne suis pas alcoolique, juste biérophile. Bref, tout ça pour dire que, niveau anthenticité, ça se pose là. Si vous avez l'habitude de regarder des films ou séries, britanniques et américaines, votre oreille (vos oreilles, pour ceux qui en ont deux) saura faire la distinction entre ces deux accents. Sans pousser jusqu'à la caricature, il va de soi, du genre écossais du fin fond de sa montagne versus cajun du fin fond de son bayou. Or, dans le cas présent, c'est indéniable, il s'agit d'un accent britannique. A noter que le jeu n'est pas traduit en français, mais dispose malgré tout de sous-titres anglais, qui favorisent la compréhension.

Ensuite, l'histoire. En quelques mots, vous pilotez un avion qui survole une zone montagneuse de l'Islande, quand l'un de vos moteurs explose. S'ensuit l'inévitable crash, qui vous sépare hélas de votre compagne. En dépit de ses blessures, elle parvient très vite à vous joindre avec son portable. Immobilisée à cause d'une jambe cassée, la pauvre est en proie à une peur panique. Avant d'être coupés, elle vous implore de mettre la main sur ses notes, disséminées à l'entour au cours de cet accident. Parce que, eh bien... "They can't find out who we are !". Voilà le décor planté, il ne vous reste plus qu'à collecter ces feuillets afin de connaître les détails de l'affaire. Entre nous, ce n'est pas joli joli... Au programme, plusieurs rebondissements et un ton résolument dramatique, lié d'abord au postulat de départ - le mot choisi est important -, puis à l'affaire en question. En somme, tout ceci est bien ficelé et fonctionne d'autant mieux que le couple Stanley / Leonore est crédible.

Que dire d'autre ? Le gameplay se résume à marcher, marcher, ramasser un feuillet, le lire, puis marcher, rejoindre une source de chaleur afin d'éviter l'hypothermie (en Islande, ça pèle mon pote !), faute de quoi vous devrez recommencer depuis un checkpoint, lesquels ne se trouvent jamais bien loin. Où en étais-je ? Ah oui ! Marcher, marcher, répondre au téléphone, s'efforcer de rassurer Leonore, marcher, marcher, écouter ce brave Stanley se plaindre qu'il se gèle les miches, marcher, marcher, découvrir l'un des rares objets nécessaires pour progresser, marcher, marcher, activer un mécanisme, puis marcher et marcher... c'est bon, t'as pigé ?

Te ferais-je l'affront de rappeller qu'il s'agit d'un simulateur de marche ? Autrement dit, sans mauvais jeu de mot : tu sais très précisément où tu mets les pieds, mon ami. Ceci dit, ces interactions et interruptions, aussi ponctuelles soient-elles, n'en demeurent pas moins variées et régulières ; au point de devenir salutaires. Salutaires au sens où elles rendent notre cheminement plus animé et donc plus intéressant. Au même titre que la contrainte sur l'hypothermie, d'ailleurs, même si ses conséquences sont dérisoires.

Ainsi, The Fidelio Incident ne tombe pas dans les travers habituels du genre, à savoir tout miser sur la narration et/ou la contemplation. Et le joueur a donc la sensation d'être davantage qu'un simple spectateur, au cours des quelque deux heures qu'il dure.

Verdict : 4/5 - Très bon, une valeur sûre !

Vous avez aimé cette évaluation ? Retrouvez-en d'autres en suivant notre curation : On les préfère froids. Et pour ce qu’il vaut mieux éviter comme la peste, c’est par ici : La Purge.
 
Berserkr

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
3.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 mai 2017
Produit reçu gratuitement

J'ai presque cassé ma manette sur Super ghouls'n ghosts avant hier, il était donc urgent que je me mette à l'aise sur un jeu sans difficulté particulière.

Le début du jeu met dans l'ambiance : on est en avion, et on se crash en plein coeur du froid Icelandais. Notre femme a atteri à l'autre bout de la région et est coincé, en train de mourrir d'hypotermie. Le but du jeu sera donc de la rejoindre pour la sauver, tout en ramassant des extraits de son journal intime éparpillés sur notre route de façon un peu trop pratique pour servir l'intrigue.

De prime abord ce qui frappe, c'est la tronche du jeu : c'est beau. L'unreal engine envoit la purée et tous paramètres réglés au max, on se prend à prendre quelques panoramas glaciales en screenshot. Pour nous accompagner dans notre randonnée, Stanley, nous même en fait, et ses monologues plus ou moins sous titrés (anglais uniquement). On récuperera dans les couloirs imposés des items par ci à utiliser par là. Le jeu arrivera à vous ennuyer sur certaines phases. Non pas par leur difficulté, mais parcequ'on sent bien que les développeurs sont plus doués pour l'écriture que pour le level design. Des evenements inoportuns viendront ponctuer la courte aventure (2 heures) de Stanley pour vous arracher à l'ennui.

Le jeu est trés bien écrit, l'histoire, interessante. Le jeu est bon dans l'ensemble mais même si je sais que c'est experience dîtes "narrative", un peu plus de gameplay ou moins de couloirs évidents auraient été la bienvenue.

+
C'est jolie comme tout
L'écriture de bonne facture

-
Linéaire à l'extreme
Anglais uniquement

NOTE : 6/10
 
Grosjaune

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Non recommandé
3.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 octobre 2019
C'est lourd... que c'est lourd ! ... Trois heures du jeu en pèsent vingt-quatre sur mon cerveau... Oh ! Pauvres bougres des grandes surfaces de la sphère vidéoludique californienne, jeunes hommes qui croient découvrir un nouveau continent en parlant d'amour ! ... Débarqueraient-ils en Europe qu'ils s'en croiraient les premiers explorateurs...

... "Il est mon coeur et je ne peux pas vivre sans coeur"... Wouaf ! Wouaf ! Bla-bla Bla-bla... Assez ! Taisez-vous ! ... Tout ce gaspillage ! Tous ces mots perdus en paroles frelatées ! Des discours pleurards sur la détresse humaine, la culpabilité et le sacrifice rédempteur ! ... Paroles christiques de gens lourdauds ! "Le profond silence de la maturation ne les visite jamais", dirait Nietzsche ; ils pataugent en couche dans les bacs à sable déjà retournés par les générations précédentes. Mais ils n'en rougissent pas ! ...

Ils se croient profonds ; je les vois superficiels... The Fidelio Incident ! Leurs créateurs sont hors d'état de penser des choses fines. Incapables. Leurs têtes fonctionnent avec des mécanismes huilés aux clichés, des tas de clichés mystiques démodés depuis un siècle ; de vieux clichés morts vivants sur des liaisons mourantes, entre les prêcheurs de la rédemption du dimanche et les pécheurs pénitents du lundi, entre le prêtre et le salarié ; entre la nécrose religieuse et la névrose fidèlement pieuse, la place est à l'incident Fidelio, à l'amour insipide encore une fois sacralisé, la millionième fois ; l'Amour avec un grand "A", l'Amour comme un grand Dieu ...

... Une petite idée commune célébrée par des développeurs ordinaires, répétée en boucle avec les mêmes imperfections d'un disque rayé. Seraient-ils les sujets d'une IRM cérébrale que le corps médical les diagnostiquerait morts ; ils ne réfléchissent plus, ne pensent plus rien que des idées reçues à l'état de décomposition. De ces idées, ils ont cru devoir en faire un jeu. Voyons.

La partie se lance : Accident d'avion. Dispersion. Jules et Juliette sont séparés. Leur amour est en péril... "Je te retrouverai, mon amour"... Bla-bla ... Le jeu commence : je marche. Fait froid. J'dois pas rester trop longtemps éloigné des sources de chaleur. Compris.... Je marche... Une grotte... Je marche... "Je te retrouverai, mon amour"... Bla-bla... Je marche. Tu marches. Il marche. Elle marche. On marche. Nous marchons. Vous marchez. Ils marchent. Elles marchent. Le joueur marche... "Je te retrouverai, mon amour".... Bla-bla... Je marche... Flash-back oniriques... Je marche seul... sans témoin, sans personne... Je marche... : Le jeu se termine... comme il a commencé... à pied... en marche...

Pourquoi ne pas avoir fait de l'histoire un livre ou un film ? A quel moment l'idée d'en faire un jeu vidéo est parue bonne ? Firewatch à un fonctionnement similaire, mais autrement plus captivant ; parce que le protagoniste échange souvent avec un autre personnage par l'intermédiaire de talkie-walkie. C'est entraînant. Ici, le talkie-walkie est bien présent, dans la poche ; mais les développeurs ont décidé que le joueur n'était pas capable de laisser appuyer le doigt sur la touche "Z" pour avancer et d'écouter un dialogue en même temps : on a donc un talkie-walkie... cassé. Inutile. Seule l'amour recherchée, Eleonore, peut communiquer ; on l'entend sans pouvoir répondre.

Au fond, pourquoi pas.... Pourquoi pas... Pourquoi pas ?! ... Parce qu'elle n'utilise le talkie-walkie que deux ou trois fois sur l'ensemble de l'aventure... et par tranche de vingt secondes... Pourquoi ?! ... J'veux dire... on sait depuis le début qu'elle est en détresse, qu'elle a une jambe cassée, qu'elle est coincée, immobilisée et apeurée... Pourquoi ne parle-t-elle pas plus souvent ?! Est-ce que l'excuse de la coupure ne serait pas un peu facile ? ... Passe le temps à écouter notre personnage, Stanley, souffler de froid et de fatigue... Alors, certes... quand on écoute Eleonore parler, on s'dit que c'est pas forcément plus intéressant que d'entendre Stanley haleter... mais quand même...

Passez votre chemin. Ne pas recommander un jeu, c'est fort ; c'est pas simplement reconnaître un ou deux défauts, c'est penser qu'il n'a aucun intérêt. Pour moi, ici, c'est le cas. Aucun intérêt. Aucune originalité. Et le pire, imaginez, c'est que le scénario n'est pas mal écrit ; il est simple, archi-simple, mais pas mal écrit. C'est l'histoire qu'est une cacade ; un étron bien sapé, un Mr. Hankey sur son 31, moins l'humour ; un Mr. Hankey dépressif... Une perte de temps. Allez voir ailleurs : On ne perd jamais mieux sont temps qu'en évitant de le perdre.
 
Life is Perceval
410 produits enregistrés
11
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
4.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 avril 2020
Pour les passionnés de jeu d’aventure au concept narratif avec un zest de survie.
Avant de commencer, sachez que notre avis se porte uniquement sur la qualité et son résultat actuel.

D’un peu plus près
Vous vous retrouverez dans une situation pas très confortable au cœur même d’un accident.
Il vous faudra vous adapter à l’environnement après ce n’est pas de la vraie survie donc pas de recherche de nourriture, ni sensation de soif donc il est inutile de partir dans un scénario où vous allez manger le /la collègue. (de plus c’est un solo)

Ceci dit attendez-vous tout de même à avoir une réflexion sur la thermorégulation de votre personnage et ainsi éviter les crises d’hypothermie.
Cependant, le plan psychologique est très intéressant avec son histoire un peu glaçante et sans faire de jeu de mots avec l’environnement.

Prise en main du jeu
L'interface est totale épurée, rien d’anormal pour un jeu narratif
Les mouvements du personnage restent toutefois très inflexibles sur l’autonomie du joueur.
(pas de saut, la course limitée ou très lente parfois, cloisonnement de certaines zones sans possibilité de réduire le trajet de passage joueur)
La visibilité très correcte.

AUCUNE TRADUCTION – vocal et sous-titres
(Messieurs les développeurs il existe de très bons traducteurs – Même si pas parfait 50% au minimum c’est toujours mieux que 100% de rien.
Prière de passer le message merci d’avance. ICI c’est la Gaule !

Il y a cependant en début de partie, une ravissante petite séquence d’intro qui vous met clairement dans le bain et vous percutera ainsi pleinement dans la narration.

Environnement – Carte & graph
Le développeur a clairement visé le contenu narratif plutôt qu’un pseudo open world, vous pouvez tourner en rond mais pas vraiment vous perdre, tout est fait pour clairement retrouver votre chemin.
Le passage de la glace est TOP TOP !

Au commencement la structure du jeu semble très hard mais finalement très accessible pour tout type de joueurs.

Concernant la musique, elle est relaxante, immersive et pêchue par crescendo.
De très bon placements pour porter le dynamisme des scènes.

Il manque quand même un minimum de présence animaux extérieur et intérieur (complexe & grottes).

Conclusion
Le concept même de jeu vidéo est clairement au rendez-vous.
Le choix du scénario est très bon.
Il m’a fallu 2h pour le finir 1 fois, oui c’est court mais c’est quand même un travail raffiné pour ce qu’il en referme.
Pas de traduction … vocal et sous-titres (soyez bon en anglais vous en aurez besoin…)

À consommer avec ou sans modérations ! Voilà tout est dit alors sortez couvert !

Merci à vous d'avoir tout lu, n'hésitez à suivre notre curateur ICI . Les critiques et vos avis sont les bienvenues et surtout... n'oubliez pas de vous amuser à bientôt !

Infos et discussions:
> Le Bar est OuVert [discord.gg]
> Le Bar est OuVert group
> Curateur Steam - Communauté d'évaluations
> Le Twich Ôbar [www.twitch.tv]
> Facebook & informations du domaine du jeu vidéo [www.facebook.com]

 
LBEO | Gryphon [FR]

Évaluation publiée le 6 avril 2020
Fidelio est une très bonne expérience de jeu graphiquement sublime avec un style Myst-like et un level design exemplaire qui vous fera voyager, un poil court le seul reproche que je lui ferais serait technique impossibilitée de régler le framerate de la carte graphique qui chauffe beauccoup pour faire baisser le bruit même via une commande console dans les fichiers alors que cette technique fonctionne dans d'autres jeux sous Unreal, un peu dommage !

Évaluation publiée le 14 juin 2018
The Fidelio Incident est un jeu narratif / simulateur de marche d'une durrée d'environ 2h (succès compris).
De bons graphismes (UE4), un level design assez moyen et très linéaire, mais servant assez bien l'intrigue, dont on devine peut-être un peu trop facilement le dénoument au vu du grand nombre de panneaux rouges et blancs disposés tout le long du jeu.
Je recommande lorsqu'il est soldé ~5€.

Non recommandé
2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 octobre 2017
Un peu déçu par le jeu. L'intrigue est clairement de qualité, au même titre que la narration et les doublages ; mais je n'ai pas pu m'empêcher de trouver le gameplay rachitique (même pour un walking simulator) et les environnements parcourus assez vite redondants.

Le moteur graphique ne m'a pas convaincu non plus. Je joue en 1440p et malgré les différents réglages poussés à leur maximum je n'ai pas retrouvé la qualité visuelle des différents screenshots proposés sur cette page. Peut-être que le titre n'est tout simplement pas optimisé pour les résolutions suppérieures au 1080p. Je lui donne le bénéfice du doute de ce côté.

Là ou en revanche je manquerai d'indulgence, c'est sur la question de la durée de vie. En moins de 3 heures tout est fini. Beaucoup trop court pour être dûment apprécié, The Fidelio Incident se prend, pour moi en tout cas, les pieds dans le tapis.

3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
2
Recommandé
2.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 juin 2017
Produit reçu gratuitement

As some of you might already know, walking simulators are a genre I particularly enjoy. I noticed The Fidelio Incident recently and was stoked when the developers decided to slide a copy across the ethereal surface of my existential wooden desk. There were a lot of things in the game's description that seemed like they would elevate the walking simulator experience to a new level. A dramatic story isn't necessarily a revelation, but a walking simulator where you hope to be rescued at the same time that you are trying to avoid anybody knowing who you are is definitely a new twist in this genre, and having the professional voice acting talent to support the project is also a nice feature. Plus, walking simulators in an Arctic, or at least very cold setting aren't exactly frequent either. So, how was The Fidelio Incident?

Story

The story in The Fidelio Incident takes place in a remote island of Iceland. You play as Stanley, who along with your wife Leonore, are flying to Iceland to start a new life together. A key aspect to the story is that they are actually fleeing from somewhere and hope to not only start a new life, but also with new identities. However, mid flight, a bird strikes their plane's window and they end up crashing on a remote island. The plane is torn asunder during the descent and Stanley and Leonore end up separated as their parts of the plane crash in separate areas. After you come to, you must try to find your wife while also surviving freezing temperatures in an unknown location.

The suspense of both the situation and the story as it unfolds makes for a compelling journey. As Stanley tries to find his way to where Leonore is, and as the elements become more extreme and daunting, Stanley starts to withdraw a bit into his mind and so the journey isn't just to save Leonore, but indeed is also a journey of self discovery and awareness. He will also discover pages of Leonore's diary that were strewn about, and which reveal a lot about both Stanley and Leonore, who they were, how their relationship developed, and how things led to where they are now.

I thought the story to be quite engaging and interesting with, at least in the video game world, and unusual twist to the approach the story takes. 8.5 out of 10

Gameplay

The gameplay in The Fidelio Incident, as with most walking simulators, is pretty straight-forward overall. You will largely walk around investigating parts of the plane's wreckage while trying to find your way to your wife. Aside from walking, there are a couple climbing sequences, a couple swimming sequences, and your basic interaction with objects, primarily Leonore's diary pages, but also other object needed to complete puzzles or simply needed to survive under certain circumstance.

Since you landed on a frozen island without the proper protection from the elements, you will need to figure out a way to survive sub freezing conditions. Standing near the fiery pieces of plane wreckage is one way, but you will also encounter steam vents that will warm you up as well. These also function as save points in the game, so if you die from exposure, you will end up at the last fire or steam vent you were standing at.

The puzzles in The Fidelio Incident are typically sequence puzzles, meaning you will have to do a sequence of events in a specific order to progress. Although not particular daunting, a couple of the puzzles will require a little bit of exploration to solve and simply require finding a specific object. The rest are as mentioned: perform actions in a specific sequence to unlock the your ability to progress. Although this can seem like it would get boring, the actual level design makes it never boring and in fact the puzzles allow you to partake a bit in the world around you making it a bit more engaging.

Speaking of level design, instead of random edges of the map, where the edges aren't obvious, there are tons of stinging jellyfish on the shores that prevent you from just wandering off and make for some entertaining dialogue as well. That aside, although you can wander about a bit while outside, overall, this is a fairly linear experience that transitions seamlessly from one area to the next.

The gameplay in The Fidelio Incident was spot on. The controls were tight, performance never dipped under 60 FPS for me, and I encountered zero technical issues at all. I played with a gamepad without issue, and also set F12 to the reset button for easy screenshot taking.

9 out of 10

Graphics

The graphics in The Fidelio Incident were flat out stunning where they weren't designed to be gloomy, and where they were, the level of detail was spectacular regardless. This is a game that WILL capture your imagination, and the setting also lends itself to a bit of sight-seeing. You will almost definitely take screenshots galore while playing this.

The actual outdoors, in the arctic levels of the game, were simply spectacular. I especially was impressed with the little details, such as the mysterious blue ice known to appear in glaciers and such, the glow from the jellyfish, and the way in which ice, water, and snow interact with each other. The plane wreckage was very cool looking as well. Once you get indoors, the setting changes to exactly how you would think of an underground bunker or facility looking. Dark, grimy, and generally unpleasant as walking amidst tons of concrete slab could be.

Later, as you start to get into the world alteration sequences centered around your self discovery, the set pieces become even more amazing. From swarms of insects to an Irish pub, you will always feel like you are exactly where Stanley is in the game. The appearance really helps serve to transpose yourself into the experience yourself.

Finally, the way the diary sheets are presented also look great. They look like something you would find in a person's diary and are very nicely detailed as well.

9.5 out of 10

Audio

As much as the other aspects of The Fidelio Incident shined, they simply could not outdo the amazing voice acting work by Glenn Keogh and Bess Harrison, who truly became their respective characters. Whether Leonore on the phone talking to Stanley while waiting for him to find her (she is trapped, immobile, freezing to death, and yet also at risk of burning to death btw....pretty grim) or reading Leonore's diary sheets, Bess conveyed real emotion and a clear understanding for the depth of the character she was portraying. Likewise, Glenn as Stanley was so completely believable and effective that you really couldn't help but hang on every word of dialogue and hope for a happy conclusion to this even. Basically, they humanized these characters in a way you rarely see in a game and really allowed for the player to connect with them on an emotional level as well.

The soundtrack was also phenomenal. Michael Krikorian did an amazing job of capturing the soul of the game in every moment, with a perfect soundtrack for the experience.

Beyond that, the other audio was also on point, but the voice acting and music put their stamp on The Fidelio Incident and elevated the game to a level that most contemporaries will find difficulty reaching.

10 out of 10

Verdict

The Fidelio Incident ended up being one of the best experience I have had with a walking simulator. I took me almost two and a half hours to complete and was, in my estimation, the perfect length for this game. This year has been great for standout titles in the genre, and The Fidelio Incident not only manages to nestle itself firmly into that greatness, but in fact comes out as one of the best of all time.

If you found this review helpful and would be interested in supporting my Curator group, it would be appreciated. Cheers. https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32549618/
 
robilar5500

Évaluation publiée le 26 décembre 2017
Fidelis

Most walking simulators showcase landscapes with forests and meadows. Fidelio, on the other hand, takes us close to Iceland where Stanley must survive following the crash of his plane. While he is desperate to find shelter he also needs to think of the other passenger, his wife, Leonore, who also managed to stay alive. During our journey we need to press forward towards the inland and occasionally need to find some objects and turn some levers in the relevant order.

Fidelio

This game looks gorgeous. For me the most captivating were the scenes taking place in the icy caves (albeit there were few and they were rather short) and sections throughout the forest that is on fire. Stanley regularly receives a call from his wife (too bad this is only a one-way communication) who orders him that all their documents be collected so that nothing is left behind for unwanted eyes. It is unfortunate that of all the achievements this one in particular is bugged and even after collecting all 30 items this was not granted to me.

Faithful

The accompanying music is great and is freely available as an extra downloadable content. Stanley's story is quite emotional; emotional not only because it is a journey of survival and of finding your loved ones but it is moving as by collecting all pages you'll soon learn this man's very past he wants to forget. I rarely complete walking sims twice in quick succession but this game, incidentally, opens up that list.

Recommandé
2.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 avril 2020
Crim's Humble Opinion Curator

Acceptable Walking Sim
The Fidelo Incident is a pretty decent walking simulator game with light puzzle mechanics and a heavy narrative. you play as Stanley who is searching for his wife after a plane crash on a island that is freezing cold. The voice acting is strong and well done. The visuals and scenes are nice. The game play can be rather simple, but the story and atmosphere was captivating enough to keep me interested for a one shot session. There are collectibles throughout the game and although it is mentioned that you have to get them all in the story it doesn't seem to change anything if you get them all or not.

The Minor Gripes
As some reviewers have mentioned when you get in the game the visuals is not as crystal clear as shown off in the screenshots on the storefront. That is because this game uses a variety of effects. Between chromatic aberration, motion blur, and film grain there are several effects that players may find less enjoyable that are meant to build to the environment. Luckily there is a user that has made a guide on how to change these settings around to your liking since they are not present in the game options. The other gripe I have is really only because I am a completionist. There are 30 collectibles to obtain over the course of the game. They have to be obtained in one playthrough and there is no chapter select. While this is a fairly short game; it is still a bit of a pain to have to go back and collect them all again if you per chance miss one near the start of the game.

(っ◔◡◔)っ ♥ pros ♥
+Strong Narrative +Nice scenery and environment
(っ>▬<)っ x ♥♥♥♥ x
-Some visual settings have to be tweaked through file manipulation -No chapter select and collectibles do not carry over

The strong narrative and interesting underused Arctic environment made this purchase for me a nice one. I enjoy these darker narrative games like Firewatch, Vanishing Of Ethan Carter, and Dear Esther. I picked this up on a heavy sale and it took me around two hours to complete it. Check out the store video and if grabs your interest; i'd say pick it up sometime.

𝕀𝕗 𝕐𝕠𝕦 𝔼𝕟𝕛𝕠𝕪 𝕋𝕙𝕚𝕤 𝕋𝕣𝕪

Recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 avril 2018
The fidelio incident is what some people may call a walking simulator, while that it technically true, the game shouldn't be defined by this title.. It's a story driven game, you find your fun in driving along the story and finding out what happened. Discovering the past while moving towards the future I like to say..

The Story

The game starts off with Stanley, flying a plane across a desolate area (which I'm pretty sure is supposed to be islands on the outskirts of Iceland), on a delivery run. A mishap with some birds, sends the plane hurdling into the ground. In the aftermath of the crash Stanley awakens to discover his wife is missing and his plane has been totally destroyed.. Upon setting out to search for his wife, Stanley uncovers a story years in the making.

Told through journal entries and flashbacks the story unfolds before your eyes.. Will Stanley find his wife and escape this frozen island, or will the secrets from the past consume him..

Gameplay

If you've played any of the number of walking simulators out there, you get the idea of what the gameplay will be like.. You explore the island, collect various items, flashlight, journal entries, etc etc etc.. This one includes a frostbyte mechanic which means you'll die from to the elements if you fail to keep yourself warmed up.. via either fires or steampipes.. The game has some some swimming, which plays out nearly identical to other Unreal games with swimming..

The story continues after completing certain objectives. The puzzles in the game are fairly straight forward and shouldn't present too big of an issue.. The collectibles are fairly easy to fine, (I found all but one of them in my first playthrough.) and did a quick second playthrough to finish up the achievements..

Pro's

Beautiful scenery,
wonderfully emotional story
amazing graphics and sound
tremendous voice acting
Achievements


♥♥♥'s

no replayability at all
fairly linear terrain
Price is a tad high for 2 hours of gameplay

Recommendation

The game is marvelous, the story is awesome, the graphics are good, and the pacing is wonderful.. The voice acting is also top notch most of the time.. The only issue for me comes from the 2 hours of gameplay, I did two playthrough in 3.2 hours, the first one took me slightly under 2 hours, the second one I rushed through to finish off the journal achievement.. While 2 hour games aren't an issue, if they are priced in the 4 - 6 dollar range, this one was 9.99.. So I'd be reluctent to pay full price for it..

With the price issue put to the side, I'd highly recommend this game if it's on sale, might even be worth the full price if you aren't too picky about getting the highest amount of gameplay out of your money..

If you love wonderful stories in your games this will be for you.. If you enjoy beautiful scenery this game is for you. I personally loved this game, and I'd recommend you buying,, as I think you'll love it too... Unless you're a pew pew pew.. kill kill kill type of guy or girl..



 
Orge Lambart

Recommandé
3.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 juin 2018
The Fidelio Incident is a story-driven 'walking simulator', i.e. a first-person adventure game with some light puzzling. It's definitely one of the better entries into the genre, so if a good walking simulator is something you can enjoy, I recommend picking up The Fidelio Incident as soon as it's discounted by 50% or more.


Story

Stanley and Leonore are the most Irish couple you'll ever come across in a game. They're on the run from the authorities when their small plane crashes on an unknown island off the coast of Iceland.

As is often the case in walking simulators, the story that unfolds is twofold. You get one story set in the present, when Stanley goes looking for Lenore after the crash. And you also get a story about their past, how they came to being on the run in the first place. Actually, there is a third story to discover by playing The Fidelio Incident, but talking about that would inheritently mean writing a major spoiler, so I won't.


Gameplay

The Fidelio Incident's basic gameplay is very simple: you can move Stanley forward, back, right and left, you can make him run (this key is frequently disabled for storytelling purposes) and you can interact with certain objects in the game world. You can rebind the default keys for these six actions as you please.

Stanley needs to keep warm, so you'll have to guide him from one warm place to the next. The plane crash caused the pages from Leonore's diary to scatter around the island. Seeing as you're part of a duo who doesn't want to be found, it may be a good idea to gather all of these pages. This is very much optional, but the pages do tell the background story of the couple, so it's recommended to collect them for that reason alone. Unlocking the only missable Steam Achievement would be the other reason.


Graphics and sound

The world of The Fidelio Incident is satisfyingly varied. The seemingly endless snowy planes you find yourself on at first are later alternated with less cold forest areas and even with some areas from the couple's past in Ireland, by way of a few flashbacks.

Graphics look very decent. Not as picturesque as top titles like The Vanishing of Ethan Carter but on par with any of the second-best class of walking simulators.

The musical score is low-key and ultimately forgettable, but it's very atmospheric and fitting. There aren't a lot of sound effects but they sound decent enough.

Both Stanley's and Leonore's voice actors do a great job bringing the Irish couple to life as much as they can. The remaining voice acting is mediocre, though.


On Steam's extra features

The Fidelio Incident has 6 Steam Trading Cards, even though the Steam Store page doesn't mention this. 13 of the 14 Steam Achievements are unmissable. The one missable achievement is granted for collecting all 30 pages of Leonore's diary, which got scattered around the island.

Évaluation publiée le 24 mai 2017
Interesting story, wonderful voice acting, haunting music...very half-lifian in terms of simple puzzles and a few times during the game I was genuinely moved (the music really works here). Some of the things on screen basically shout the general storyline and it's not hard to figure out the ending well before the ending but that's ok...in some game formats (like this one and Dear Esther) it's ALWAYS about the journey and how you get to the end and what you learn is much more important than the end. There were a few glitches (I could phase half-though a few doors, the plane crash sequence was...choppy, I'm not sure a single achievement worked, and my gametime counter only showed a half-an-hour when I played a good 2.5 hours) but none of them took anything away from the game. In terms of the "Walkers" I've played...better than Dear Esther but not quite Firewatch (that's not a bad thing mind-you but IMHO Firewatch was brilliant and it's in my top 10 games of ALL TIME) and getting something original and story-driven makes me happy. 90% FD Score. Buy it!

Non recommandé
3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 octobre 2018
Rarely I feel this compelled to write a game review. However, this game cast such a strong opinion upon completion so I had to write it out.

I am a self-branded "walking simulator" enthusiast, and I hope to embrace all kinds of storytelling attempts in this medium. Among the games that I played, there are clearly better ones and worse ones, yet I am not sure how to rank this one fairly among them. If it is just either "Recommended" or "Not Recommended" as required by Steam, I would say I cannot recommend it to a general gamer because I don't consider it to be as enjoyable as it should be. On the other hand, for any of you who likes to compare playing games to art appreciation or is even a game developer yourself, you may want to have a thorough run yourself instead of taking my word for it. YMMV and I hope you enjoy more than I did.

For readers hoping to have a few more paragraphs than an executive summary, read on. While it should be spoiler-free, it does give out a few plot-related observations.

===

Let's start with better parts. The visuals are stunning; it runs fairly smooth on my aged rig. There are games in the genre that have compromised graphics or opted for alternative aesthetics to cope with the often limited time and budget. This is not one of them. The island presented is a photorealistic experience. Also, the music is absolutely tremendous and immersive - and I would highly recommend getting the soundtrack as well to support the developer.

And here comes the rougher parts. First regarding the voice acting. Let's not be picky over accents, although Leonore's lines sound pretty weird to me throughout the run. I am not alone on that, and you probably have read similar notes from other commenters as well. Maybe it is because, just as Polygon's Colin Campbell noted, that Leonore's Irish accent sounded phoney. (On the other hand, Stanley's acting feels much more natural.)

The dialogue design is plain and straightforward, and that speaks for both the spoken parts and the in-game text. We are definitely not looking for Shakespearean prose here, but the lack of subtlety and intimacy in the use of words makes the otherwise mystery-filled experience almost laughable.

The story itself is hit-or-miss, depending on how deep a player can personally associate with it. For the storytelling to work, players must try to understand and perhaps empathise with the protagonist Stanley. It requires the player to think like one in a local conflict to relate to the agony of Stanley, but it may not work for everyone.

These are the weaker aspects of the game, but not one of these alone is really fatal in the way to deliver a meaningful and enjoyable experience. The worst offender is the game mechanics - mainly the freezing mechanics.

The story is set to be on an icy island, and the player acts as a character that has to survive through the elements. The player character will be frozen to death standing idly in the storm. With this in mind, players are encouraged to stay warm by staying at the marked locations in the map instead, usually represented as fireplaces or steam wells.

In a sense, this mechanic is smart, and I can imagine a few reasons why it got implemented:
- It provides a visual guide to direct players where to proceed with the story.
- It also acts as a good source of gameplay puzzles.
- The design is so in line with the narrative.
- Best even it presents a sense of urgency and survival to the gameplay at the same time.
Yet, the price it asked for is to deter players from exploring the gorgeous game world significantly. This deliberate design choice hinders players from getting off-track in a heavy-handed manner and forces them to proceed at the game's designated pace.

Arguably, exploration, or the illusion of it, is the most fascinating element for "walking simulators". In other experiences, when players collect clues at overlooked spots, those moments reward players with surprise and satisfaction. While this game also has optional collectables (Leonore's journal), their placements are pretty much predictable that finding them feels much less like a treat but more an obligation.

And nope, story linearity, in contrary to what is reported by some reviews, is not the main reason why it does not work. It is true that the gameplay does not hold player's hand over any hard decisions (there aren't any anyway), but to me, it is the conflict between the game mechanics and the narrative that reduces the experience to a dull and shallow rail ride collecting items despite the unusual choice of setting. That is actually quite a shame given how much the developers are seen attempting to do.

If you decide to try it anyway, I recommend referencing to a walkthrough to Leonore's journal while playing. The 30 collectable pieces give out core plot details and can be missed as the game proceeds. Once lost, these can only be acquired again by doing a subsequent playthrough from the very beginning, filling with identical sequence and unskippable scenes, as there are no ways to start from a particular chapter. I did my first playthrough for half an hour before noting that there are missable collectable items, and thus I restarted anew and did a complete run from there. The total playtime is a little more than 3 hours.

On the other hand, for a similar experience, I highly recommend giving Dear Esther a try (both the mod version and commercial release are fine). Frankly, not everyone would like it, but players who have played both games may see how much inspiration has been drawn from there. One may also try The Vanishing of Ethan Carter for a visually pleasing narrative. It is not without its ♥♥♥♥ (just like any other), but one would feel the individual game elements are woven into a tighter and more polished experience.

(Originally posted on Oct 3, 2018. Last updated on Apr 2, 2019, for typos.)
 
Kelvin
659 produits enregistrés
0
13 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
2.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 juillet 2020
The Fidelio Incident covers some history that games don’t cover much at all in “The Troubles” part of Irish history. It is by no means meant to be historically accurate to a certain person, more a general overview of how it affected these fictional characters. You can piece together what happened to them by finding various pages of your wife’s journal after your plane has crashed. The story is fantastic and while I guessed the ending fairly early it was still a fun journey. The game has some puzzles to solve so it isn’t just a walking sim but many of them are pretty easy although they succeed in their goal of breaking up the game play and adding variety. The game adds a feature where you will freeze to death if you don’t find warmth in a certain amount of time. This sounds annoying but it is enough time that I only found myself dying a handful of times. The music was very well done as was the voice acting. The graphics were a mixed bag. The snow and vistas were great but the fire and trees were pretty poor.

I played The Fidelio Incident on Linux using Valve’s Proton. It never crashed on me and I didn’t notice any bugs. There is one graphics setting as well as 4 AA settings and a Vsync toggle. The game is locked to 60 FPS regardless of whether Vsync is used. Alt-Tab doesn’t work. There is no manual saving option, just checkpoints. There is also no indication of when these checkpoints occur. The game uses the Unreal Engine 4. For the most part the game ran at 60 FPS but it could have sudden drops that lasted a few seconds and the drops could be severe and with no credible cause.

Disk Space Used: 10.39GB
GPU Usage: 1-99 %
VRAM Usage: 1962-3615 MB
CPU Usage: 4-17 %
RAM Usage: 3.4-4.6 GB
Frame Rate: 1-60 FPS
Game Settings: Epic for both

If you enjoy walking sims I can easily recommend The Fidelio Incident. I finished it in 2 hours 24 minutes which felt like a good length. I paid $1.09 CAD for it but it is easily worth it’s current full price of $10.99 CAD. It’s story, music and voice acting really make it stand out. Similar games would be Layers of Fear or Fire Watch.

My Score: 8.5/10

My System:

AMD Ryzen 5 2600X | 16GB DDR4-3000 CL15 | MSI RX 5700 XT Gaming X 8GB | Mesa 20.0.7 | Samsung 970 Evo Plus 500GB | Manjaro 20.0.3 | Mate 1.24 | Kernel 5.7.0-3-MANJARO | Proton 5.0-9

Recommandé
3.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 juillet 2017
"Oh God! Not ANOTHER walking simulator!" I hear you cry.

"Sit down...shut the ♥♥♥♥ up...and LISTEN," I reply.

Alright, so I've been playing a few of these lately, and all you "this isn't even a game" people are probably getting mighty sick of all these products even existing. Well, y'know, sometimes life is hard. Sometimes, you don't get everything you want in this world. And sometimes, just sometimes, things come along which can defy even the expectations of those who swore black-and-blue that they'd never, ever embrace them.

Let's break it down, shall we?

First up, something these "walking sims" actually DO tend to be praised for: graphics. The Fidelio Incident allows you to choose "Epic" graphics quality, and I have to say, that's exactly what you get: epic graphics, from the get-go. You begin in the cockpit of a plane, and it isn't long before that plane is crashing thanks to a bird selflessly splattering itself across the windshield in high-def. So no, this isn't quite your typical walking sim.

Secondly: sound. Top-rate, highly immersive sound design and very good voice acting. The occasional naff line of dialogue ("Ooh, blimey...so ♥♥♥♥♥♥' COLD...need to get warm")...but hey, it IS a video game. Get over it.

Thirdly: danger. Yep, there is some. Quite a bit, actually, mostly due to the harsh and unforgiving icy environments most of the game is set in. You will die. Possibly quite a lot. So again...not your typical walking sim.

Fourthly: gameplay. The path isn't 100% linear, and there are some (granted, reasonably simple) puzzles to solve. So there is some traditional notion of "gameplay", for those of you who are truly fussed about such things. (Poor bastards, haha.)

Fifthly: length. Okay, so it's not "epic" in length. Nor should it be. I'm sick to death of long games for the most part. A game well under five hours might put some hair on yer sac...try it.

And last but definitely not least: story. It's a good'un. A real good'un. Told well. You like stories, don't you? Oh, that's right, you only play Call of Duty. (Sorry, couldn't resist.)

On the whole, it's a bit like Kholat (minus the monsters), with a tiny hint of Tomb Raider and the bit when you first crash-land on the icy planet in Dead Space 3 thrown in. High adventure and epic storytelling at its finest. Heck...with a little luck of the Irish, even avowed haters of walking simulators might find something to love here.

You never do know, eh?

Verdict: 9/10.
 
rjmacready
2,949 produits enregistrés
4
12 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 septembre 2018
A 3 hours long journey, in average, this walking simulator provides. It is one of these games that the less you know about it, the more enjoyable it will be when playing.. Thus, i will merely scratch the surface in this short review without going any deep.

You are a couple, quite old by now. You are on a plane of your own going through a frozen distant island that is located somewhere near Iceland. The plane crashes and the two of you get separated in this island. As a husband, your only mission is find your wife and reunion again.. That's pretty much it. The whole way you will be exploring your pasts through your memories, or should we say, nightmares and your wife's journal that its pages are scattered all across the island. That's pretty much how the story progresses which is fairly decent.

What i find the best about this game is its visuals and atmosphere.. You will feel the cold in your bones behind your screen.. There is no place that feels safe in this island.. You can't possibly stay in the open for few seconds without a heat source else you die.
Some landscapes and views you will come across are simply, breathtaking. The whole journey will feel brutal, yet satisfying.

Once more, it is a walking simulator with few "primitive" puzzles that are only there just to add some value to the gameplay itself. It got a decent story (Not that great but not bad at all). I would only recommend it on a sale because it doesn't feel like it deserves the full price, at least not for 3 hours of experience it provides.
 
Sabfas
823 produits enregistrés
0
24 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 juin 2017
Produit reçu gratuitement

If you enjoy this review please consider following my Curator page here .

The Fidelio Incident wears its inspirations on it sleeve and wears them proud. Boasting likenesses to Dear Esther and Firewatch, Fidelio sets itself up to fill some big shoes. In the end, it mostly succeeds if not falling a bit short of its lofty goals.

The Fidelio Incident is the newest entry in the burgeoning genre of Walking Simulators. There seem to be more and more coming out, especially by small studios, so it can be a bit hard to stand out from the crowd. One thing that definitely helps Fidelio is that it’s drop dead gorgeous. Made in Unreal 4 (which I’m a sucker for) Fidelio exhibits a high visual fidelity that really makes it stand out from the crowd. I found myself positioning myself for just the right screenshot multiple times.

The story presents itself fairly straightforward, but of course not everything is as it seems. While the inspirations to Dear Esther and Firewatch do ring true on most accounts, Fidelio does continue the quickly tiring trope of document/diary pages to collect. There is nothing inherently wrong with presenting a narrative this way, it would be nice to see progression past this and new vehicles to deliver the story. This is not entirely Fidelio’s fault, but if you’re looking for something you haven’t seen in the genre before, this is not it. Along these lines, the diary pages that you pick up are accompanied by voice over work in addition to text. The VO work is one of the stronger aspects of the game but unfortunately you have to wait with the page open to hear it all. If you close out and continue playing, the VO stops. Now I know that perhaps it makes more sense narratively to only have VO play while the note is open I found myself getting slightly irritated when I had to sit there and wait for it to be over. This is all personal taste, but I would have preferred a Bioshock-like presentation where I could listen to the VO while still exploring since the actors do a great job.

In addition to the voice work, I found the soundtrack to be quite excellent. Inspired Beethoven’s opera, there are obvious classical tones and on overall sober ambience that reminded me some of Radiohead and Nine Inch Nails, two of my favorite groups. The dark soundscape really adds to the oppressive atmosphere and you ascend the mountain.

The gameplay itself is pretty standard fair with the addition of the freezing mechanic – finding heat sources to prevent yourself from succumbing to hypothermia. I found this to be very reminiscent of the 2009 title Cryostasis. Fidelio thankfully implements this to where it’s not a hindrance or annoyance but adds a bit of tension as you explore.

Taking around two hours to finish I found The Fidelio Incident perfectly enjoyable, if not a bit predictable. It doesn’t necessarily bring anything new to the table but what it does, it does well. While it doesn’t ascend to the heights of What Remains of Edith Finch or Gone Home, The Fidelio Incident is still a fine addition to the genre and one that should certainly be played if you’re a fan of its predecessors.
 
ParanoidAndroid

Évaluation publiée le 18 aout 2019
pros

- icy and cold winter atmosphere
- repetetive but easy puzzles don't break immersion
- nice and atmospheric musics
- intriguing story with psychological narrative
- very good voice acting
- game is not short
- some realistic approach to a character who is in sort of situation. he can die from hypothermia and gets frozen if you expose to cold weather too much.

♥♥♥♥

- there are many technical problems and glitches. game is especially turns out to be buggy/glitchy mess towards to end. a general level loading problem for some people since there are multiple threads with people stuck in different places with black or white screens and nothing loading. because of these problems finishing this game is an chore.
- low framerate and laggy engine
- grainy graphics
- bad interface
- some direction would be great

despite all these frustrating technical problems, this is an pretty decent Dear Esther inspired walking simulator with some light puzzles. i think this game many ways better than Dear Esther. there is interactivity and puzzles and you can involve much more to game. i liked and recommended it.

Évaluation publiée le 23 novembre 2021
As a Northern Irish person I can say that The Fidelio Incident is a game about Northern Irish people made by people who have never been around Northern Irish people. Apart from the actor playing the lead role who is actually from Ireland, the accents from the remaining cast are so appalling that it becomes completely distracting and actually hilarious at times. I mean, they're not even the right accent from the right country. That would be a good starting point, like.

Add this together with numerous factual and cultural errors and you've got a smelly pot of insulting diddly-dee Oirish bollocks (or "bullocks" according to the game's subtitles).

Then the game itself: a walking simulator and exploration game that likes to kill you if you try to actually walk around and explore anywhere. Largely pointless puzzles and annoying 'walking about in the dark without a flashlight even though you actually have one' sections really don't add up to a pleasurable experience.

It's only two and a bit hours long but honestly don't waste your time with this. Especially if you're actually Irish or Northern Irish and don't wish to have your day ruined by this offensive load of ♥♥♥♥♥. Just do something else instead. Wash your windows. Clean out your toaster. Buy a sleeping bag. Anything. Anything but playing this.

Please.

Évaluation publiée le 11 janvier 2018
The Fidelio Incident is a walking-simulator that you could finish in two hours.

The game has an interesting love story in the middle of Iceland after a plane accident, some puzzles to solve using steam pipes. and some diary pages you also need to collect if you want to complete all the achivements.

Good use of the Unreal Engine 4, good voice acting and good sound and music.

It's far from Firewatch but I think it's quite good if you buy it cheaper in sales
 
[CGC] |CG| VLMBcn
2,936 produits enregistrés
3
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 janvier 2018
The Fidelio Incident heavily focuses on story and journal pages as you go through the game, as do many games that are tagged with "walking simulator." However, I really enjoyed the setup for this game, as well as the environment and general gameplay.

You play as a man named Stanley, who has just crashed into some set of islands in (or near) Iceland, and his wife got separated from him in the crash. You must make your way through (mostly linear) areas to find the wife, Leonore, as well as keep yourself alive from the cold ice. There is some suspension of disbelief in that Stanley seems to function perfectly fine after the accident and you also do not have to worry about food.

However, you do have to worry about the temperature as you can die if you stay out in the cold too long. You can find fires or steam coming from pipes or the ground, which can "cure" your growing hypothermia pretty quickly. Again, that breaks reality a little bit as running between hot and freezing cold over and over would not be good for a person, but that is pretty much the main requirement to progress in the game.

Besides the above, you will occasionally find some puzzles, but they are not extremely complex. The most often occurrence is to have to change the direction that steam goes through certain pipes in order to open up frozen doorways, or to keep certain hallways warm enough for you to travel down. There are also a handful of places where you need to explore a little bit to find certain items to continue along, such as a flashlight or ice axes for climbing.

That pretty much sums up the game: You make your way through the cold island(s) to find Leonore, while collecting some journals from Leonore along the way that give backstory, as well as encountering certain dialogue or cutscenes that give more story progression as well.

Even though the overall gameplay is relatively simple, I enjoyed the environment (especially with the graphics) and main plot more than I did in some other popular walking simulators (such as Dear Esther, which I found extremely boring). My last comment will be that the game can be completed in about 2 hours, so determine which price you would being willing to pay.

In the end, I enjoyed the short time I spent in this frozen land.
 
Dravvad
0
7 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 novembre 2018
Follow "First Person Exploration and Puzzle Games" for more games like this!
A surprisingly good walking simulator. The game tells the story of a husband who wakes up alone after a plane crash, and goes looking for his wife. It claims to be inspired by a Beethoven opera, but the story and gameplay have nothing to do with classical music.

There are a few simple puzzles, but this game is purely a story-centric walking-simulator, not a puzzle-game. Aside from walking from place-to-place, the only other real gameplay involves finding the nearest fire to avoid freezing to death. Sometimes this requires solving a puzzle, but usually you just need to look around. Don't worry, this is definitely not a survival sim.

The story, music, atmosphere, vocals, and overall polish of the game are good-to-great. The game looks and performs well; my only complaint is that the frame-rate is locked at 60fps. There's about 2.5 hours of gameplay.

This game was a hidden-gem. It reminds me a lot of Firewatch; if you enjoyed that game, or are a fan of walking-sims in general, you should definitely check it out!

0
Recommandé
4.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 juin 2020
now this game was a huge surprise.

basically everything about it is great. graphics, music, atmosphere, voice acting, storyline, background story and all that good stuff. an actual indie game and a high quality production. you don't say that often in the same sentence.

the story provides a certain sense of urgency to your actions and so does the cold. but you can deal with the cold fairly easily and it doesn't stop you from enjoying the game.

i think this is the first walking simulator i played that manages to combine plausible gameplay & plot with an actually realistic & deep background story. so this time you're not playing as somebody walking down a path in a magical forest filled with unicorns. this time it's "real".

finishing the game took 2.5 hours (ocd-grade exploration) plus some extra time for 100% achievements. playing the game a second time to collect all the pages of the journal actually made me appreciate the story even more.

really impressive. one of the best and most interesting walking simulators so far.
absolutely recommended for everybody interested in the walking sim genre.

Recommandé
2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 janvier 2019
Wonderful adventure game / walking simulator. Great story, although I guessed the ending way before I got there, which is unusual for me. Also, the puzzles were simple, which I count as a plus in this type of game. Making the puzzles too difficult in a walking simulator game just destroys the continuity of the story and makes it disjointed. That was not the case here. The story flowed nicely and kept me engaged the whole time.

I'd also like to mention that the saving mechanism in the game is perfect. I press "Quit" and the game exits to desktop, automatically saving my progress exactly where I left off. You mean I don't get punished for having to go to work or to take care of household tasks?? Finally a game company that gets that there are real people playing their game and not jobless automatons!

I realize this is a small company, but +1 for the short credits at the end. I've seen indy companies with 5 minutes worth of credits listing off the same 5 -10 names for a plethora of stupid jobs done during the project. Excellent decision.

Great experience. I'm definitely now a fan of Act 3 Games LLC.

Please keep that way....

Non recommandé
2.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 janvier 2018
For starters, it doesn't look as crystal clear as the screenshots suggest and I had everything on Epic. The Fidelio Incident is an act of running to your wife, but only when sprinting is allowed, solving puzzles and collecting pages of a journal along the way. You and your wife got separated during a plane crash over Iceland. You fight hypothermia by running from one vent to the next, from one fire to the next. Hot air is used to solve most of the puzzles in the game by rerouting steam via pipes and there's no need to assemble or rearrange pipes. Nevertheless I appreciated the bit of puzzle solving there is, cos it adds to the immediacy of your wife freezing or burning to death. Few of the hypothermia runs were very close calls, but you can easily see where you need to go and survive.

Your wife asks you to pick up the pages of her journal that got scattered during the crash, for reasons I won't get into. You may or may not find all of them on your first run, I missed two of them, but they don't stop you from reaching your wife or change the outcome of the game. I realize I'm taking most of the lure out of a 3-hour game by even talking about it. The voice acting is nice, especially if you love the Irish accent, but some of the dialogue and exposition was a bit heavy-handed. I didn't like certain sequences and generally got annoyed with the game during the last hour or so. The pacing of trying to save your wife and reading her journal pages with her narration just doesn't work for me, not sure if it'll work for you. I suggest picking it up during a sale. It's a general Yes from me, but I'll vote No in this case.

Worth a buy, If you enjoy short story take place in icy island. However, if you're not sure, please continue to read and find your answer.

PART 1
Please calculate your "YES" score to identify the value to buy:
If your answer is unsure, kindly consider it as "NO"

  1. Can you understand the frustration of freezing weather?
  2. Can you understand the responsibility for taking care of your wife?
  3. Can you understand the feeling if your family member is a prisoner?
  4. Can you understand the importance of hiding the real identity?
  5. Do you like a love story?
  6. Do you like a hot temper character?
  7. Do you love Beethoven music?
  8. Do you feel scared if discover animal dead bodies?
  9. Are you able to accept radial motion blur as a recap memory effect?
  10. Are you able to accept turning valve to be the core gameplay mechanic?
  11. Are you able to accept short gameplay about 2 hours?

Please total up your honest score and find the category here:

YES range
Tick one
Result
9 ~ 11
You will like it
6 ~ 8
You have mix feeling on this
3 ~ 5
You may skip it
0 ~ 3
This is not the game for you

RollWave
0
5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 avril 2018
The Fidelio Incident is a technically-sound, gorgeous, 2-hour romp through some mountains as you wander around picking up garbage (journal entries) that tell a story that is ultimately unsatisfying. It's about as vanilla as you can get and for the "walking sim" genre, you need to bring a whole lot more to the table than this. They call it a thriller, but there's nothing thrilling about it.

There's really nothing to bash the game about. The guys know their Unreal Engine and use it well. There's no game-ending bugs, the voice acting is top notch, and the pacing is pretty decent. The game is beautiful. The puzzles aren't overly silly and at least they exist, so it gives levity to the "move forward" aspect of the genre. So why the thumbs down?

We come to these kinds of games for their stories, hoping to be wowed in some way by some strange twist or the revelation of great mysteries. The best of the genre all have the elements of discovery and surprise as their foundation - Firewatch, Edith Finch, etc. Just those titles alone tend to evoke some strong emotional memories with players who loved them.

The Fidelio Incident, on the other hand, has no mystery, no twist, nothing that surprises you. It weakly attempts mind games (as all these games do), but the entire story is telegraphed harder than someone gathering a horde of zerglings inside their base. This wouldn't be so bad if the story was actually something that at least demanded to be unraveled; instead, your character is detestable and unrelatable and as you begin to learn about his wife, it's hard to think highly of her as well. There's nothing that really draws you, the player, into the game to place you in the moment and make you feel like this could be happening to you. The entire time, it's absolutely happening to someone else, and if it weren't for the monetary overhead of purchasing the game, nothing was really there to drive me forward. The mind games start pretty early as well, so there isn't really much to ground the experience. It's really weird. Things like this should be effective, but for some reason, Fidelio doesn't pull it off.

I suppose if you have some Irish background, you'll get more out of this game than I did, but while it's technically-solid, I just don't think the story is worth your time. It's a mediocre, straight-down-the-middle effort and you may enjoy it like so many others here, but for me, the unrelatable characters and knowing the ending way before it happens deflated the Fidelio Incident before it even had a chance to start moving.
 
Dune Tiger
5,620 produits enregistrés
0
10 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
1.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 mai 2017
I just finished this game in one sitting, and the experience is still fresh enough that I can say that I fully understand their inspirations from games such as Dear Esther and Firewatch, and that they are well founded.

As with most walking simulators, the gameplay is pretty minimal, some simplistic puzzle solving and fortunately not too much backtracking. A two hour experience to be sure, but I feel the purchase was well justified for the experience, the story, and the visuals that were presented.

Pros:
=Great atmosphere - The locale and paths were beautiful and fairly well designed, even if it suffered a bit too much linearity, including the occasional invisible wall.
=Beautiful graphical fidelity, photogenic views. (Dear Esther level of shutterbug)
=Great voice acting, nice conviction and some very well conveyed emotion.
=Light gameplay elements that both encourage and discourage appropriately.
=Fantastic parallel story, seasoned with Irish revolutionary history and a loosening sense of what's real.
=Absolutely fantastic musical score, I hope they release an OST!

♥♥♥♥:
=Story doesn't -totally- wrap up at the end, you're still left wondering why certain things were the way they were, given the explanations at hand.
=Freezing gameplay element encourages rushing through, when the point of a walking simulator is to walk.

Issues:
=Encountered the very occasional clip (carried door clips through the ground, saw through the ground for a brief moment while getting up)
=Had an obvious invisible wall near some pipes in the cave, even though the space was big enough.
=Got stuck in the "among the dead" area because of a lack of a way to jump out of what became my inch-deep death. (between some bones)

TL;DR -- A walking sim that for all intents and purposes, conveys it's message and it's story serenely and almost totally satisfactorily. If you liked Dear Esther or Firewatch, this is right up there with the great interactive narratives.

9/10

And even though it's not the best game I've played this year I wouldn't give back my time with it, and I'd encourage other people to play it too.

Recommandé
2.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 mai 2017
Short with about 3 hours of gametime, but it drew me in as much as Firewatch did.

Good story, graffics, voicing and some small puzles along with a good twist makes this up there on the top list with some of the other best walking simulator games with narative story.
 
Legionnaire
2,706 produits enregistrés
1
5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 juillet 2017
Wow....I am in awe. This game, was less of a game and more of an experience, a journey. The immersion was so very well done; the sound design was some of the best that I have ever experienced in any game, wonderfully placed enviornmental sounds, fantastic voice acting, and absolutely beautiful music (the soundtrack is free to listen to once you get the game!!). The graphics are a treat for the eyes, containing cold, wintery landscapes and views of a surreal world where you are never quite sure what is real or fiction. It featured a story line that was engaging and held my interest tightly. I had some FPS stutters at a few points, where it dipped from 60 to 40 while on max settings and the graphics options are very sparse, you cannot change individual settings yourself. However, I am not very upset about these flaws as this is an indie game and the developers did so many other things well. I applaud the creators of this game and will be looking forward to future work of theirs.

Bottom line: If you are looking for a walking simulator with very few puzzles and an amazing storyline: you must buy this game.
 
Screamin' Beave'
186 produits enregistrés
1
5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 octobre 2021
This is an interesting story-based game with some light survival elements, exploration and puzzling. You play Stanley, a plane crash survivor trying to find his wife after their plane crashes in Iceland. You're trying to find her before you freeze to death. Meanwhile, you stumble across pages of her journal which tells of your life together, and your connection to The Troubles in Northern Ireland.

The gameplay was engaging enough to keep me interested, and the puzzle elements were simple. Not very challenging but it fit the game which focuses on exploration and story-telling. There isn't much direction on what to do but it feels very intuitive and Stanley's voice lines also give sufficient direction. I was seldom confused or stuck, even if it took me a bit of time to work something out. The voice acting is excellent, the graphics are quite beautiful and the sound design and soundtrack are good and atmospheric.

Performance was a bit of problem with some FPS drops and occasional stuttering.

Overall, recommended for fans of narrative-based games and walking simulators.
 
MadBone12
518 produits enregistrés
0
7 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 juin 2017
I liked this game. The story is good, and although it helps to know what was going on in Ireland about 30 years ago, it is not necessary. The story gives enough details, if you pay attention. The puzzles aren't too hard, although I did get stuck a couple of times. It's not a long game. I played it through in 3.5 hours and that includes a fair bit of wandering in circles, because I couldn't find the right route (even though the game is very linear). Some things you need to do in the game don't make much sense, considering the environment, but it gets a bit weird towards the end anyway, so I just ended up trying everything, no matter if it made sense or not. I paid a little under 10€ for this and I think it was a fair price.

Évaluation publiée le 27 décembre 2017
" The Fidelio Incident " is a visually enhanced Indie Game By Act 3 Games, inspired by Beethoven's only opera Fidelio.


The Fidelio Incident is a single-player, first-person thriller set off the coast of Iceland. After a violent plane crash, You must search a desolate frozen island in search of your wife Leonore while covering up any traces of their bloody Irish past. Story was good and little bit confusing. Unreal Engine 4 make this game stunning looking. With all achievements this game took 4 Hours for me. As a short indie game it's worth buy in sale.

Pros:

1. Amazing Visuals.
2. Detailed Environments.
3. Easy Achievements.
4. Great Voice Actors.

♥♥♥♥:

1. No Chapterwise Playing Option.

9.5/10.

Évaluation publiée le 24 avril 2018
This game is decent for a 2hr play through, the graphics are alluring, and the game mechanics are technically-sound.
As a walking simulator its pretty good, You walk around a beautiful mountainscape (trying to get to your wife), releasing pressurised air from a piping system throughout the whole island, to help you navigate, either to keep warm or to clear a path. Along the way you pick up your wifes journal entries, which help you uncover the story, that end up being somewhat unsatisfying.

I finished this game in 2hrs.
