0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
9.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 juillet 2019
After a controlled flight into terrain (crash landing) on a small isle near Iceland you get separated from your spouse and have to get to her asap as she's badly wounded. I would describe Fidelio Incident as Dear Esther on speed. You have to run from steam vent or burning piece of your crashed DC 3 to another to avoid dying from hypothermia.
By gathering pages of your wife's diary you reveal the background of the unfortunate couple.

Kudos to the three developers for the pleasant surprise I had with their game. As to be expected this Indie title lacks some polish as you first see when you open the minimalist options interface.
On the other hand not many small teams are able to produce something decent with the UE 4 engine. Like others I experienced some hangs during transitions from one level to another but I give the game the benefit of doubt as I played on a laptop with Intel HD 5500 graphics (so no big surprise).
As a good UE 4 game graphics are beautiful (especially if you have the oomph to max them out) and the soundtrack is the cherry on top.
For the achievement hunters its an interesting title as it is relatively easy to get a perfect game (I got 13 of 14 achievements in my play through). It'll take you about 2-3 hrs before the credits roll.
 
𝕙.𝕓𝕒𝕣𝕜𝕒𝕤
5,459 produits enregistrés
0
7 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
2.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 février 2020
This was really good, a 2 hour walking sim with a good, solid story, no excessive "busy work" which ended in great satisfaction for me.

For me, the key thing in a walking sim is the feeling that you're turning over pages in a book, whether it be by moving to a different area of the game or triggering the next piece of voice over. Sometimes it's nice if the different area looks good or intriguing.

These are two areas where "The Fidelio Incident" excelled. The visuals brought the hostile, frigid rock of the frozen north to a life I've never actually seen with my own eyes, yet it feels cold just looking at it. The story walks beside you, two people travelling to a new life to something else entirely.

The puzzle sections are simple and yet satisfying (which I would consider the best type in a walking sim) and no part of this ever outstays its welcome.

An exceptionally well put together game I enjoyed massively. Well done to all involved.
 
joerice1979

Évaluation publiée le 22 octobre 2021
As a walking sim with a soft puzzle touch, it started off strong, had a very good background story, decent voice-acting, but as it developed the game became a bit of a boring chore. Realism turned into surrealism, repetitiveness settled in big time, and the only thing that kept me interested was the scattered backstory journal pages that I needed to find. It was even better than the main storyline which only left me with a bad aftertaste.
 
Prophet
1,379 produits enregistrés
0
8 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 mai 2019
Way back in 2007, an unexpected yet excellent game “Bioshock” from 2K took the gaming genre by storm. For me, what sold it was the narrative as it fooled me right from the get-go as I blamed it on “Consolitis”. Why is that because of the outrageous starting point of the game where the protagonist injecting needles into himself without asking questions so we can get straight into the action. Well I was totally wrong as the game fully explained later on, about why you do what you do. Why I’m saying this is because this game “The Fidelio Incident” has a similar feel to it. Granted it’s coined as a “walking simulator” (for which I loath this term as most of my games I walk anyways to get into the “feel” of it – that’s another story) however it’s plays upon the experience of the main character.

The game is quite short and it’s recommended to be played around the three hours mark. For me, I realty took my time searching all the journal entries thrice throughout (and even listen to them a couple of times) and I have clocked around five hours. Because this game is purchased via the Steam client, there are fourteen achievements to collect (and they are all achievable during the first playthrough) and six cards to collect (along with the typical background / emojis and what like). The cards are just OK as they are extracts from Leonore’s journals (just the pictures). They could of be a little more imaginative here like having cards that was part of a concept art (or something to that effect).

Because the game advertises (in accordance to their website) that it has narrative, exploration, survival and puzzles, the only thing that’s got going for is the narrative as the other three (exploration, survival and puzzles) are in very small quantities. However, there is an enveloped underlining theme – that is, understanding the mindset of the main protagonist Stanley and his quest to locate and save his wife before it’s too late. And as a sidenote, this also can make a great movie flick too.

7.5 / 10 – Whilst it promises narrative, exploration, survival and puzzles, the narrative exceeds everything else. However, play it for the experience as, after all, life is a collection of experiences.

Full review: https://www.gamespot.com/the-fidelio-incident/user-reviews/2200-12788075/
 
Azghouls

1.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 juin 2017
I don't usually get games like this, but I enjoyed it.

The best parts of the game are the visuals and graphics... stunning, but also the ending. Once you play the game and see the final screen. It all makes sense.

Gameplay is pretty good, not the most exciting. A couple of very simple 'puzzles'. The game heavily makes steam your friend (the boiled water, not this). No action or anything, just walking/running and interacting with something occasionally.

I completed it in 1.5 hours in one go. Its pretty short, I don't think its worth the full price. But if its on sale (which is when I bought it) give it a go.

The audio and narration is very immersive, A good game

20 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
2.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 juin 2018
The Fidelio Incident is a first-person thriller that is set on the coast of Iceland. After you (Stanley) and your wife (Leonore) survive a brutal plane crash. But you were separated from the crash, so you must search and explore the frozen island for you wife, while covering up any traces of your past life.

I picked this game up when it was on sale and can say it was 100% worth it, even if the game can be completed in-between 1-2 hours. ‘The Fidelio Incident’ must be one of my favourite games and must be one of the best games of this generation (for me at least.) I loved the story, I’m usually not one for game graphics but I thought the graphics in this game was phenomenal. I also enjoyed how the 2 stories being told fitted into each other. I liked the survival aspect of this game and as well as the voice actors, which did an incredible job. The game was great for saying it’s a walking simulator.

If you don’t mind the short story then you should pick this game up, as the scenery and story alone is amazing and would win me over
 
Rehzerehzy
339 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
1.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 novembre 2021
The Fidelio Incident is a linear story-based game with a fairly easy and short playthrough (I'm at just under 2 hours at full completion). The story is somewhat tragic, focusing on the sacrifices people make for love, tying in quite nicely to the inspired Fidelio opera. I enjoyed searching for every detail I could find, and though there were no in-game repercussions to dying, I liked the "survival" aspect nonetheless.

I'm giving the game a positive review overall because it was indeed a good story and the sound/graphics were pretty decent. However, be advised: this game has issues working on Intel 10th Gen+. There is a workaround in the discussions board (thank goodness), but I had opened the game about 5 times trying to change graphics and such while it kept crashing to desktop before I checked there. There is no setting to adjust motion blur or film grain, which is always frustrating. In Fidelio's case, the film grain was advantageous to some of the scenery, but motion blur is and will always be atrocious.

I do believe this game is (for the most part) worth the $10 value.. but for the play time and the fact that this game isn't working right off-the-bat with newer PC specs I'd say to try and get it on sale.

Évaluation publiée le 5 septembre 2017
It's a decent game, well put-together, and has a few twists that it throws you.

It's also the kind of game that you go into, expecting a mind-f**k - and you do get one, it's just not "it was all a dream", the most typical of mind-f**ks in this genre.

Is it worth playing? The best I can put it is, if I could erase my memories of the game and leave myself with a recommendation, that would be: "If you're actively looking for a game to play, it's worth $10; otherwise, buy it on sale. You won't fall madly in love w/ it, but it'll entertain you for a cpl/few hours."

Recommandé
2.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 juillet 2018
I got this game for around $1 during the summer sale. Took me around 2 hours to complete, I think it was totally worth it.

This game falls into the category of “walking simulator”, there are some lite puzzles but for the most part you are walking around listening to the dialogue of the characters while searching for the story based collectibles. I really enjoyed the story overall, it covers a part of history that is rarely explored in other games, tv or movies. All of this accompanied with the great music had me completely immersed in the universe that the game had set up.

Overall if you enjoy other “walking simulators”, then you are probably going to like this one too. I know I sure did.

Évaluation publiée le 17 avril 2018
A Beautiful Indie Game
Never expected a indie game to be that much beautiful. The graphics is really really EPIC considering a indie game. I humbly thanks to the developer for not making the puzzles much harder to solve which many of the indie games do. The gameplay is simple and story is deep but understandable. I finished the game along with all achievements within 2 hours. There are some pros & ♥♥♥♥.

[+] Brilliant Sound Effects.
[+] Beautiful Graphics.
[+] Great Voice Act.
[+] Good Optimization.

[-] A bug could cause game being stuck on black screen and the last level of the game won't load. *I got past this problem lowering the resolution & getting back to my original resolution when the level loaded.

Despite having beautiful graphics & OK story, this game might be not feel worthy at full price. So give it a chance on sale!

2.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 mai 2017
BEAUTIFUL! Simply, beautifiul.
This game has very stunning visuals, crafted in a way that makes it feel almost real life. --Would be really interesting to play in VR. But not only is the visuals stunning, the story is thoughtful and immersive. Tragic at times, and thrilling at others. Yes (I know I can be a softy), but I did shed a tear or two reading the journals.
Basically, the premise is that you're wrecked on a deserted icy tundra in search for jounral entries and your wife. Not only are you having to battle the elements, and a mysterious group of people in the bunker, but you also have to battle your nightmares to survive. Maintaining your sanity is key.
I've never been one for walking simulators, as I usually find them boring. But the story is captivating enough that it keeps me interested and wanting to know more as I continue.
If you want to watch me play an hour's worth, give my video a look! If not, that's fine too! :)

2.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 décembre 2018
Two hours may be short by the standards of gaming, but it feels long in this walking simulator, which simply doesn't have enough intrigue to sustain it. By the time the game enters its visually impressive final half-hour, the protagonist's backstory is so evident that further revelations feel redundant and tedious. The game also flagrantly wastes players' time by playing voiceovers only when the journal is open and not while the player is walking, thereby becoming the equivalent of the lecturer who reads his PowerPoint slides to the audience.

FoxyPantaloons
546 produits enregistrés
0
7 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 janvier 2018
The Fidelio Incident explores the story of a youngish couple in the aftermaths of the North Ireland Conflict. Stanley, the male protagonist and the player's persona, and his lover Leonore seem to have a criminal past - involved in a terrorist attack on a public house in Northern Ireland.

While the background of the characters of The Fidelio Incident is beautifully explicated, the gameplay is mostly nothing but derivative lever switching. The level design relies heavily on the four metaphoric stages of hypothermia, which are hinted at bluntly on a sign almost right at the beginning - so you don't have to play through anything you didn't expect. The narrative had a lot of potential, but none of it is told in a way that might have impact on the recipient. It creates no emotional tension or identification - and calling it a 'thriller' is gross misadvertisement.

Maybe if you're born in Ireland and have relatives who were involved in the North Ireland Conflict you might think of it differently, but from a distant standpoint The Fidelio Incident did not at all cash in its premise. It rather seems like a Bay-ish firework that relies more on the spectacle than on actual impact - and to achieve that it's, all graphical abundance aside, even missing the spectacle.
 
[SeL] Belbo
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
1.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 octobre 2018
Credit where credit is due, it takes real creative guts to tell the story this game does. Without getting too much into spoilers it goes to a dark place I haven't seen breached in almost any other game. It's quite striking, if slightly overwrought at times.

In terms of the gameplay, you can expect around 100-120 minutes playing time. A lot of it is admittedly simplistic vent puzzles, and warming yourself cryostasis style to avoid freezing. Fortunately you do not lose progress on freezing. I'll say I wasn't the biggest fan of this form of gameplay as I struggled to connect it in a meaningful way to the story until the very end. Regardless, it doesn't annoy enough to detract from the story.

I played through it on one sitting, and interestingly in the same way cryostasis made me feel a little ill at first, so too did it. Might have been my video settings or maybe I'm just afraid of freezing to death.

Anyway, for story-centric gamers I'd say this is worth it on deal. I'd price it at solid $4-6 maximum.
 
Sardonic
955 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 juin 2017
First off, I would say that I personally enjoy walking simulators and I happened to come upon this game as I went through my discovery queue to get my 3 trading cards for the summer badge thing. I came and looked at the page and was quite interested and that I had to buy it which I did instantly. The graphics are amazing although there are some points where you get some lag spikes/freezing but that only happened every 20 mins or so which didn't really bother me. I love the story and it was quite in depth. There are points where it did take me some time to figure out how to advance, so that may be one thing to point out. So, make sure to fully explore. I do recommend you get this game, espescially with it being on sale. For me, it seems like a mix of Firewatch and The Solus Project in my opinion, just made more simpler. I finished the game quite quickly I would say, in just 2 and a half hours. Overall, I believe that the game is a good pickup for 10 dollars.

Non recommandé
2.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 septembre 2017
I rarely write reviews, but i just feel like this time I have to for people to avoid my own mistake. Reviews are mostly positive and people talk about some touching story, great soundtrack, amazing visuals and so on. I didn't see any of that. It is a mediocre game at best.

The story is boring and obvious right after you see the first "Hypothermia" sign. Graphics are ok, soundtrack is not bad as well. There are no puzzles, you just walk along the corridor path with no alternate route, there is no choice for the player to make in the game. I did not feel immersed in the story, I simply walked through the game without feeling anything except frustration and boredom. The game takes 2 hours to complete, it's not worth its price.

Just go buy Firewatch if you're looking for a walking simulator. This game is not worth your time or money even on sale.
 
rooskie
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 septembre 2023
Dream in the heights: a hypothermic adventure of an undeserved love

I

I like how this game closes: the scene of the crashed plane and a warning signpost is on the side. It contains the message of the four symptoms of hypothermia. Although it insinuates being inspired by Beethoven's opera, Leonore, oder Der Triumph der ehelichen Liebe, an inspiration compelled or far-fetched, the game nonetheless offers a story worth experiencing. It has a re-adaptation, though a modern love theme.

The story commences with a plane journey piloted by Stanley who is accompanied by his wife Leonore. While they’re having a tête-à-tête, some birds crash into the windshield and the engine that shoves them to collapse into the snowy and mountainous landscapes of Iceland. They both survive, so the husband resolves to go rescue her while they try to endure the cold before going into a state of hypothermia.

I enjoyed the route the plot thread was developed. The game proposes to represent the stages of hypothermia. Each one of them are performing with a particular scenario. Although it’s presented as an uncluttered and minimalist landscape, with the hike its image and representation changes as the plot discloses. The journey is discreet and symbolic. Its path goes from reality to dream, where at each pace the character confront his most intimate problems and traumas.

II

However, upon hearing their voices, entreat to listen to his wife, I asked myself: what are they escaping from? Until now I don't want to divulge the details. It’s better to experience them in the game. Conversely, an answer to the question is unearthed in the pages of Leonore's diary. There she tells me about both of their pasts, as well as their personal, intimate and historical context: a time of The Troubles or Na Trioblóidí that occurred in the North of Ireland. All of this is encapsulated in a script that accomplishes to express their emotional burdens.

What I didn't like was the narrator's lack of tone for Leonore. Sometimes her voice stopped or discontinued forcefully due to the deficiency of rhythm in the writing the diary. It has a rhythm between prose and free style poetry, which is better reflected in the dialogues of both including that of the other characters (voice-over) and some of Stanley's soliloquy. The voice intermingles with solitude and steep silence.

As for the game, it consists of a walking simulator and solving some simple puzzles. The character has simple movements. Nevertheless, when walking in the cold, the character can die (this is perceived when the screen shows frost). Hence, certain spots have thermal sources in order to progress in story. And as in the game Dear Esther, the storyline will steer the player to the peaks and then descend in a last attempt to say goodbye to his beloved wife.

III

Finally, the soundtrack is beautiful, it’s expressed in adagio sostenuto through the piano. It was composed by Michael Krikorian and inspired by Beethoven's opera as bagatelles. It performs a pathetic event to underpin the drama of both characters and achieves to concentrate its atmosphere towards the tragic outcome, a concluded story, of the spouses. I like how Leonore's loneliness be conspicuous as a contrast to the snowy landscape of Iceland.

On the other hand, the game is quite short. It just takes a little time to listen carefully to the pages of the diary. This is an indie game with a worthwhile story. This is similar to short stories read in bed under a blind lamp, while the tinkling rain slides softly over the windows.

Recommendation: 7/10
 
Aletheia ❀
0
13 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 juin 2017
Produit remboursé

I usually like this sort of game (Having recently played Dear Esther, Vanishing of Ethan Carter and Everybodys Gone To The Rapture), and do not get me wrong, this is in no way, shape or form, a 'bad' game. Let me explain TL:DR.

When you first play, you realise how beautiful it is, how good the voice acting and sound effects are, and feel really in tune with the atmosphere. For this, I absolutely do applaud the developers. They have done a fantastic job of making you feel within the confines of the island and the temperament of the weather.

The main reason for playing a game like this, in my eyes, is the story. The story is very intriguing and it got me wanting more until an hour or so in when, despite telling myself otherwise, i'd realised what the ending may be.

SPOILERS AHEAD

My prediction was that the events taking place on the island are all in your mind - that stanley is actually in prison and it would come around to this eventually. I then realised that he was not in prison, that he was just remembering past events and that in fact he was there on the island, just trying to get to the top of a mountain.

This in my opinion is a very anti-climactical ending that could have really been developed upon much further than just turn a valve and that is the end. Nothing new really came of the last 30/40 minutes of the 3 hr experience (less if you don't take in the jaw dropping visuals). I felt a connection to the lady up until I realised that we just get there, turn valve, thats it. It felt premature.

I really wish there was a neutral rating on here rather than just yes/no, because although I dislike what eventually became of the story, I love the rest of the game. I can recommend this for the price, but IMO the developers could have done much more with it.
 
RykerFive5

Produit reçu gratuitement

Fidelio Incident is a single-player, first-person walking simulator set off the coast of Iceland. After plane crash Stanley try to find her wife and fight against hypothermia.

+ Beautiful graphics
+ Okey story
+ Good music

- Game guides you so there is no challenge.
- Puzzles are too easy and repetitive.
- There is no replay value.
- Boring

So another walking simulator.. Very linear, boring and no challenge makes this average-bad game. But... These beautiful graphics, music and okey story is reason why i ll give it positive review and guess its worth to try.., but only with heavy discount!

6/10

Recommandé
2.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 janvier 2018
Thank you to the developer and publisher Act 3 Games for making a good game for me to escape, explore and enjoy.

The Fidelio Incident is a short(2.5 hr), story focused, linear game with basic puzzle solving. It looks amazing due to the use of the Unreal 4 engine and the musical score is expertly done as well. This experience is not for everyone but fans of adventure, mystery, story driven games i think will be more than pleased with this choice. As is my critique of most of these types of games i would like to see have seen some sort of effort put into problem solving more than simply turning a wheel or entering a code to open a door.

Notes
MSI R9 390 video card
Epic settings 1080P 50-60 frames ultrawide with a few drops into 10-20 frames

Positives

Expertly made by industry veterans
Amazing environments with noticeable attention to textures
Music is strong as it plays as a character through the adventure
Good writing and voice work
Mature, unique story for a video game
Its a steal at $3-$7

Negatives

Intrigued by the mystery one second, and then its quickly revealed the next
Basic puzzle solving
Fantastic environments not utilized fully for survival or puzzles
No one to discuss some questions that are unanswered, or ending.

59 produits enregistrés

5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 aout 2017
I'm really conflicted about this game. On one hand, while essentially being a walking simulator, it has all the important checkmarks of an engaging game.

It has SOME mechanics, it has a concept it sticks to, it has a structure, it has great voice-overs. The visual design is OK as well (more on that later).

And it did engage me till the end - I finished it after all.

That said, I can't say I had fun with the game, which is why I must, sadly, give it a negative rating. Here's a quick list:
1) while the game makes good use of the Unreal engine, the world isn't nearly as "pretty" enough (the visuals are high-quality, just uninteresting most of the time) for me to want to explore it, yet exploration is "rewarded" with journal pages
2) but said journals, while containing a high-quality voice-over, aren't exactly thrilling
3) while it's nice the game has mechanics to raise it above a "walking simulator", these mechanics are more frustrating than fun
4) the entire backstory wasn't really engaging and it felt like it didn't serve any purpose at all aside from a contrived narration at the end
5) the game dips nicely into "confusion" with a lovely little start, but things go downhill; perhaps it's the backstory mentioned above just didn't grip me enough for me to care about the connections (which felt forced)? ...or perhaps the madness aspect never really kicked into overdrive to make it memorable...
6) the ending also feels hallow - it simplifies the experience and doesn't leave much to think about; again, it may be my disinterest in the backstory that's the reason for this?

Ultimately, I got the game via a Steam sale, so I don't feel cheated or overly angry. With that said, if you're interested in this title, wait for a sale. Otherwise it's way too expensive.
 
Urban Shaman

I recommend this game, but only if people understand what it is. This is a walking simulator. It has gorgeous graphics and good voice acting, but it only took two hours to beat. The game itself is pretty intuitive, because it's just, you know, walking. If you're in it for the story, as I was, go for it, just know that game-play is pretty minimal. Anacro
575 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 mai 2022
The Fidelio Incident is probably up there among the best walking simulators I've played. It tells a story in a visual and audiotorial way - much like Dear Esther - but to be honest, this game is a much better experience.

With good puzzles and interesting game mechanics, there's never really any parts that are drawn out. You're not just walking, but actually trying to survive as you're looking for your wife. There's a few "chapters", where you get through various zones and they are all beautiful. The soundtrack is well-made and fits perfect, same with the professional voice-acting.

Now I don't want to spoil anything regarding the ending so I'll leave that be, however it is a touching love story and during the game's duration you are not sure how it will actually end.

I truly recomend this game, especially if you enjoy the games that it was inspired by (Dear Esther, Firewatch and Gone Home). It's too bad that the devs hasn't made any games since, because this is a high-quality indie gem worth playing.

Évaluation publiée le 26 septembre 2017
Just finished this game in one sitting after picking it up for 6 bucks on sale today. The environment is stunning, the voice acting top notch, and the story keeps you wondering throughout. If you are up for about a 2 to 2.5 hour experience with a few not-too-challenging puzzles interspersed (although most are in the 2nd half), then you should pick up this game while it's at a nice price. It's not the sort of thing you'll likely play over and over, but it's worth more than a lot of movies I've seen at the theater for the same or higher price.

Bottom line, great job for an independent studio, and I'm glad to have supported them with the purchase.

2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 juillet 2019
Vidéo YouTube™: FIDELIO INCIDENT (Gamplay review) Ice iced baby? 
Vues : 41
The Fidelio incident. A walking sim in the snow? But will we end up with frostbite? Let's find out...


A visually impressive walking sim. The Devs have made great use of the Unreal engine, and the audio track is fitting and expansive. Voice acting is okay but not outstanding. The story is quite 'explosive' when one considers the subject matter. And of course there is the obligatory note finding to move the story forward.

So it does what walking sims do - and there are a couple of very very light puzzle moments, but the bulk of the game is walking and note finding.

A decent enough walking sim for the visuals and audio, and you can complete the game in about two hours. All in all I enjoyed it at the sale price I paid, but I don't think I would buy it for full price in all honesty.

Absolutely beautiful walking simulator/ adventure game by Act 3 Games! Im impressed by the gorgeous setting and beatiful visuals and i can see that God of War's Art Director left his mark on this ♥

On the performance note, runs maxed out stable over 60fps easily on max settings 1440p with 6700k & GTX 1070, although with vsync on i had some issues, the framerate dropped to 20-30fps for some reason but didn't have any tearing throughout the game without vsync.

8,345 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 juillet 2018
There are two spectrums on the "walking simulator" scale. One is Gone Home or The Stanley Parable, game where the world and your actions immerse you in a story and ideas coherent and compatiable with what you're doing. It's a level of immersion that few titles outside the "genre" achieve or even aspire to. Then there's Dear Esther, a game that's just graphics and voice overs that have nothing to do with each other and are essentially game design masturbation. Fidelio Incident isn't quite Dear Esther, but it's certainly more on that scale.

The general gameplay is a man trying to save his wife from a plane crash. However, to accomplish this you run around a snowy tundry collecting pages from a journal and staying warm by running between conveniently placed fires and steam pillars. As the game progresses, the atmosphere becomes more diverse and puzzles get added, but the puzzles aren't really puzzles. Instead you just run to an object to interact and a puzzle is solved. Only twice did I actually have to think about what I was doing in the entire game (a puzzle involving a big tree and an insect swarm, and another in a forest fire that involved copious backtracking). Needless to say, there isn't much gameplay in this game. There's a lot of voice overs, some nice graphics, pressing W, and a complete lack of character models which really hurts the immersion in two very key instances.

Overall, The Fidelio Incident isn't really worth the time you'll put in (approximately 2 hours) unless you really like piecing together stories through diary pages. If that's your scene, the Fidelio Incident is right up your alley. If you want problem solving and contextual storytelling, go play What Remains of Edith Finch or Ether One.
 
Charlie Brownstein

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

_Griff
0
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 mai 2017
Someone mentioned they didn't like it because they didn't know Irish politics. I thought what little they touched on had to be public knowledge. I think most people know about car bombings and violence, even if you don't know why. Irish Republicans / Catholics want all of Ireland to be free of British rule and the Irish loyalists / Protestants want Northern Ireland to stay part of the UK. That's really all you need to know for this. You really didn't even need to know that much, just that there's conflict though the violence has calmed considerable from 30 years ago. The story is more about remembrance, regret, and resolution. Both sides had a reason to fight and sometimes good honest civilians turned on their brothers over this issue. It's really a great subject to reflect on now that the violence is over and scars remain.

As for game play, it was simple. A couple times I "solved a puzzle" without knowing I did because I likely did things out of order. Only happened a couple times--got the plane door before I knew why I needed it and I opened the heavy door to get the key card without knowing I needed it or why I was opening the door. Those are minor things though. A lot of things happened that I didn't really get until after.

Opening the last value to shoo the bugs from the tree, but it didn't work, the tree sprayed out water the wrong color and a symbol of Stanley's past fell on the ground... It wasn't until after it hit me why. In that, I think the developers accomplished what they wanted--to get people talking about all the symbolism in the game.

Alright, here's the obligatory plug of my Let's Play of it
Vidéo YouTube™:  
Vues : 0
 
Lokana

4.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 septembre 2020
This one starts out promising, but quickly fades. There is no real challenge here. The game guides you in the right direction with very obvious points of interest. You can watch a walk-through on youtube and get the same experience. The "puzzles" presented are simple and absent minded, and a complete game will take under 2 hours - if you struggle. The plot twist is built and spun into a disappointing reveal, leaving no real sense of accomplishment upon completion. Also, to the achievement hunters: you must complete everything in one go. Nothing carries over to another save. This one is a skip in my book.

Non recommandé
2.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 avril 2020
A simple 'game' like this requires a simple review I think. It is a walking simulator, made famous (infamous?) by 'Gone Home', and it follows a very similar track. Walk around following a linear route, collect plot-related pick-ups as you go along, and there's some VERY light puzzling to be carried out. Look out for the absolutely daft hailstorm section, where the island has become home to some incredibly bizarre meteorological circumstances.

The game looks good enough but how in the hell, in the year 2017, does a game set in a snow location not manage to include footprints?? I noticed this within a minute of playing as there's nothing quite like a good crunchy footprint. Well there isn't any, so deal with it. There is lots of valves and pipes though. Lots and lots. They all feel very out of place in this remote Icelandic setting.

It was an exhausting trek, 2 hours wasted for a plot which became ultimately negated by what you witness in the very final shot. A lot of praise has been given for the voice acting, but it felt very hammy for the most part. The lead female role does a good enough portraying a trapped damsel, but the main character, Stanley, is over-acted to the point of being able to fit in just well in an episode of Eastenders.

To wrap it all up in to one giant nutshell; daft. And a bloody waste of your ♥♥♥♥♥♥' time.

Évaluation publiée le 28 décembre 2017
The positive reviews are not fake. This was an exceptionally enjoyable game.

Looking for an action-packed shooter? Look elsewhere. Looking for an interesting almalgum of a Beethoven opera and the IRA bombings wrapped in a walking sim? Yep.

Pros:
Length - short and without overly tedious walks or puzzles.
Artwork - the pages of the diary are exquisite; the world is OK - I wish it had been more detailed
Voice acting - it's gotta be tough to act a story like this but they pull it off. well done.

♥♥♥♥:
Polish - made on a budget and it shows but the story makes up for it.

Good game about an important period in history. Cheers. Nicely done.

dr. Magnetron
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 avril 2020
What a beautiful, heartbreaking little game.

The Fidelio Incident can best be described as an enhanced walking simulator - there are a couple of death mechanics and some light puzzle solving throughout the short 2-hour runtime, but the drive of the playthrough is the story and exploration.

The game wastes no time setting up the situation - you and your wife are split up when your small plane breaks apart over a frozen island, and you need to find a way back to her before she dies of exposure. Along the way, you collect scattered entries from your wife's diary that help to fill in the essential backstory, though there are more interactive story beats as you progress that will also elucidate the situation. This game is a character study, and learning about these people through the uniformly excellent writing is a treat, albeit a sad one. This is not a feel good game.

The frozen island you traverse is gorgeous, and liberal use of surrealist imagery keeps the entire experience fresh and the color palette varied despite the small map and short length. Performance wasn't well optimised, and I struggled to maintain 4k60, but the graphics are top-notch, especially for an indie game. Rounding out the presentation are strong voice acting and beautiful music, which fit well with the isolated melancholy atmosphere.

I was surprised to see so many tepid reviews for this game after finishing it. It may not have the polish of Gone Home or the production values of Firewatch, but I personally felt that the storytelling hits just as hard. It may not be a relatable tale, but clocking in at the length of a movie, it's one worth experiencing.
 
TheColorUrple

Évaluation publiée le 7 juillet 2019
I honestly don't know when I stuck this in my wish list. I usually go on kicks of finding games that I like and sticking them in there. A lot of the time I forget whats in there. During Steam's sales I will visit my wish list and order it by price and there was this game waiting for me at the top of the list. I of course jumped on it. It isn't very long. It is a very good adventure, puzzle game. I couldn't wait to find the next page of the journal. In most games, I don't care for collecting. It feels monotonous and time consuming. In most other games it is just away to pad game time. Not in this game. In this one the voice acting is top notch and the story is so good you will find yourself hunting down those pages to hear more about these characters and what they had been through up to the start of the game. Trust me, find those pages and listen to each one. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoyed playing Firewatch. On sale or full price this game is worth it.

3,429 produits enregistrés

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Non recommandé
2.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 décembre 2018
I'm on the fence about this one. Beautiful graphics and atmosphere, and it's obvious a lot of heart went into it. But ultimately, I had a hard time sympathizing with the main character, and for a game that's all about the story, that's not a good thing. I've played enough games with similar themes that The Fidelio Incident doesn't really stand out on its own. Perhaps if there had been a deeper focus on fleshing out the thoughts, the motivations, the humanness of the main character rather than just bits and pieces in journal entries and flashbacks that set up a predictable plot twist, then it might have struck a more meaningful connection with me. It's not a bad game; it's just not particularly memorable. It might still be worth trying if you enjoy narrative-driven walking sims, but I'd recommend getting it on sale.

Non recommandé
3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 aout 2018
It's a thumbs down for me but it's not a terrible game.

This game is a walking simulator, its pretty good on the visual side of things. There are some minor puzzles which don't require to much thinking to solve. The game has an ok story and it's helpful to have lived during the time of the IRA or have at least some knowledge of this time period and the various incidents that occurred. The story is tied up nicely at the end but i really just don't think the long slog was worth it.
There are some idiotic parts including underground bunkers with puzzles to solve and a giant tree with insects that need to be cleared by solving steam puzzels. These feel really forced to make it a "game". I really think it would have got a better feel had they just gone for more of a walking simulator instead of trying to make it a puzzle game as well.

In the end the only real thing i can see in this game for me is a possible screen shot game.

 
Fisto (Shan)
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
10.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 aout 2018
“People do not change, they are merely revealed.”
Anne Enwright, The Gathering, 2007

I played The Fidelio Incident recently (twice in fact, but more on that later!). It’s a dramatic walking simulator developed and published by Act 3 Games, LLC, it was developed using Unreal and is available on Steam for £6.99. I spent 3.3hrs ‘completing’ the game, which seems to be a little longer than average looking at other reviews. I managed 13/14 achievements, the last one involving finding and collecting 30 items that are scattered throughout the game, unfortunately, this has to be done in a single playthrough – hence my second run. Even so, I only managed to find 29/30 collectables and while I managed to not throw the controller across the room I won’t be going for a third attempt any time soon!

The story begins with a couple in a plane, flying over Iceland, the year is 2010. Almost immediately the plane crashes and the pair is separated. You, as the protagonist Stanley, must now try to find your partner Leonore. It quickly becomes apparent that the two share a secret past life in 80’s and 90’s Ireland, that cannot be discovered. Everything they need to keep hidden is detailed in a diary kept by Leonore, the pages of which are now strewn across the island – this is where the collectables come in if you hadn’t sussed that out!

The Fidelio Incident is primarily a walking simulator that slowly reveals the story fo the two main characters through the diary entries and exploration of their pasts. However, it does incorporate some puzzle and survival elements in the form of having to stay warm in the first half of the game and reconfiguring steam vents, either for warmth, deterring bugs or putting out fires. These felt novel at first and I initially thought it was a nice touch to add, however they lacked variety and quickly became a chore, I was reminded of the disappointment I felt upon realising the repetitive nature of Outlast’s ‘scare’ and puzzle moments.

I found myself thinking of another game whilst playing this, one of my favourites in fact- Dear Esther by The Chinese Room. Rather than feeling inspired by a game I love though it did at times feel like it was trying too hard to be like it. One moment in particular, relatively early on in the game I was walking into a cave; aesthetically I was reminded of Dear Esther instantly and it’s at this point that Stanley starts spewing a melodramatic, pseudo-existential “were the last 30 years even real” monologue that feels so out of place and forced and I’m sad to say I couldn’t help but cringe. There were moments of climbing, up mountain tops, stairs or similar, that had this added and superfluous tension added that again only felt like a failed attempt to replicate the poignant portrayal of ascension within Dear Esther.

Overall I enjoyed The Fideo Incident, it was visually very stunning, utilising the heat and cold to create a variety of environments and bring them to life. The music was also well constructed and suited to the game, consisting mainly of piano that often felt melancholy but built to a level of drama as the game did the so too. It’s a short game and will probably give you no more than a few hours enjoyment with little replayability (as I discovered) – If you’re going to go for the collectables achievement, I’d suggest using a guide because 1 missed item will require another full playthrough – too harsh! It’s worth playing but probably only at a discount and if you haven’t played Dear Esther yet, well just get that instead!

If you enjoyed this and would like to see my game reviews (and a bunch of other ramblings) in their natural habitat please visit my blog[rachaelbreartonwrites.com] Thanks :)
 
Arìllae
618 produits enregistrés

Évaluation publiée le 1 mai 2018
The Fidelio Incident

Story
The Fidelio Incident begins in the cockpit of a light aircraft, flying above the frozen rage of Iceland's igneous landscape.There are two occupants on the plane and they seem to be life partners who've been on the run from their native Ireland for many years. When the bifurcated plane crashes and the two are separated, the game begins. The protagonist, a man called Stanley, searches for his missing lover Leonore.

Review
It's a very well put together indie game with beautiful sights to be seen, the story goes on the further you progress. I would go as fas as saying this is a walking simulator where the story tells itself with a little adventuring and survival.

Why did he place the bomb? 6.5/10

Évaluation publiée le 12 octobre 2021
Note: Finished in 3 hours of gameplay (all journal pages found).

In general:
As much as I like indy games I can't recommend this one. It is not a game. It’s a walking simulator or interactive movie at best. There is very little in the game which could be considered to be a gameplay – you walk, you pick journal pages, you read. That’s pretty much it.

Pluses:
+ impressive icy exteriors
+ beautiful graphics
+ great voice acting
+ made by small independent studio (which is something I support)

Neutral:
+- moving through freezing or foggy enviroment can be annoying
+- some say the story is great. Well, I don’t think it’s that great. It’s OK.

Minuses:
- basically no meaningful gameplay
- quite short
- full price is just rediculous

chgojj

4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
4.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 avril 2018
Enjoyed the game overall, but had its problems

The Fidelio Incident is very story driven and involves a lot of interacting with your environment. The first section of the game was on an Irish island where you needed to survive the cold, as well as look for your wife, Leonore. When I first started playing the game, the environment looked beautiful. What really did catch my eye was areas around the edges of my screen. It became an issue for me throughout the game. Those areas around the edges appeared as though the environment or camera was trying to create a 3D effect, but in an old-fashioned way. It wasn't necessarily the lack of focus but the environment looked like there were layers of red and blue behind the textures. I also thought I needed those red-blue 3D glasses we use to use, to make 2D objects look 3D and coming towards the viewer. At first I wasn't sure if that was a bug in the game or it was a reoccurring thing. Now, I do understand that the developers may have wanted to simulate the look of viewing someone who is in contact with extreme cold temperatures and weather. I thought it was a nice touch to have frost around the sides as well to show the player that you're getting cold. But that look on the edges was just hard to look at. When I look at my direct line of sight, normally I expect it to be clear. Then those not in my direct line of sight should be blurred out or softened. I don't know if the camera was trying to do that but couldn't, or if that's mean to look like that. I think that was my biggest concern about the game.

I did like the interaction with the environment. Sometimes you'd go to one location, do an action and then move on. Then at times you were to return back to the previous area to forward your progress. I thought that was nice. I didn't feel like a look and move on type of story. Along the way, you picked up bits and pieces of your character's (Stanley) wife's journal and learn about the backstory. You learn about the kind of life these two lived before being in present day Ireland. The journal was sometimes needed to solve puzzles in the actual gameplay. I thought that was clever. It was also nice to put a voice to a person, whom you've never met, but your character is in love with. That was a nice touch.

At times, I had trouble progressing the game or I just got lost. Now, I'll admit part of that was from my own stupidity. I would at times yell at the game, complaining about not knowing what to do. Sometimes the objects that needed interaction were not lit up until I had the camera at a certain angle. It was another issue but it wasn't bad enough that it made me dislike the game.

Overall, it was a good game, despite some of the technical issues. As someone who enjoys story driven games, I thought a really well developed story was told.
 
Sweet Rabbit
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
1.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 juillet 2017
The Fidelio Incident is an interesting game, slotting into the same category as pieces such as Dear Esther, Firewatch, and even a little bit like Kholat.

Though your time in this game is mainly spent walking to point A-B so on, discovering and reading the numerous journal pages trewn across the icy landscape, and listening to the remarkably well done voice acting, you have a few puzzles to break the monotony of your journey and add a bit more depth to your endeavour.

The graphics are fantastic, the only complaint is forced Chromatic Aberration. It didn't work for Payday 2, it didn't work for Life is Strange, it doesn't work here. It is an awful post-processing effect. That being said, the visuals are otherwise clean and vibrant.

The sound design is equally as good, with crackling fire, howling wind, crunching snow and the like. Voice acting is top-tier and is clear as day. The game features a 12 piece score with the main theme being the most prominent piece. The music fits and integrates itself flawlessly, conveying and emphasising emotions, tones, and underlying themes. The piano sounds fantastic here.

Your only real downside comes from the somewhat tiresome puzzles as you find yourself repeating these quite often. The story is enjoyable and based around a real-world issue, The Troubles, which occurred in Ireland. Wrapping in just under 2 hours, The Fidelio Incident is a nice little adventure with some genuinely enjoyable visuals and premise, it's just let down a little from its puzzle design.

If you enjoy games like the aforementioned, games that are generally a single smooth pace, then this is worth checking out. Otherwise, if you prefer a little more engagement, this may not be to your liking.

Verdict: 7-8/10, recommend purchasing when on sale.
 
Garthorium

4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Non recommandé
1.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 janvier 2019
Walking simulator sort of a thing which begins with the plane your and your wife are flying crashing into an island and separating the two of you. The meat of the game then is your character traversing the frozen island, and caverns underneath it, trying to find your wife while not freezing to death and performing light puzzle solving. The backstory is told through your internal dialogue and--of course--diary pages that you find lying around which unfold a tale, surprisingly, about the impact of terrorism during The Troubles. The game looks relatively nice, possibly because the key figure behind it was the art director of God of War 3 apparently, but there's very little variety so that dulls into the background after a while. There's nothing particularly wrong with it but it doesn't do much to stand out from the glut of such games that Steam is drowning in.

Évaluation publiée le 18 octobre 2021
Walking Simulator, with Easy Puzzles.
+ Nice Graphic.
+ Nice Sounds / Background music / Voice acting (Irish Accent).
+ Nice Atmosphere.
+ You can configure controls.
+ It has Trading Cards!!
+ I did not find anything bad, worth mentioning.

If you are Achievement hunter, I strongly suggest, using a guide for Journal Pages, without it, you easily miss couple. There are no save-feature, so you can not replay a "chapter". If you miss one, you need to play whole game thru and collect all Pages, again.

Easy Achievements, 100% / ~2h.

I bought this with 90% discount, well worth it!
I loved this!

Évaluation publiée le 14 aout 2021
Very short, well voice acted, enthralling story. Mostly a walking simulator with a few "puzzles".

Pros:
Voice acting is very good. Better than a good number of AAA games.
The story is very intriguing and not a story that I recall being told in another form.
I felt rewarded for exploring. Unsure if I got every item but each item adds to the story.

♥♥♥♥:
The controls are clunky but I also used a controller.
The controller keymap settings were unable to be modified without crashing the game. But the defaults were serviceable.
Some of the environment is difficult to know what can and cannot be traversed. The rules are unclear as you cannot get up an incline in one location and in another a higher grade incline is easily able to be walked up.
~2 hour game time may not feel like enough bang for buck depending on how much you purchased the game for.
 
the_nil
332 produits enregistrés

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 avril 2019
With themes of terrorism/freedom fighters, father-son dynamics, and the price of love, among others, the grand concepts and topics behind The Fidelio Incident are generally well handled and developed. Something like this could easily be trite and conceited but instead gives the player a look at complex topics with no easy answers.

The gameplay leaves a bit to be desired (if it's hard to put the price of love and terrorism into a empathetic story, gameplay is only more difficult), being largely atmospheric walking and climbing through the desolate, violent Icelandic environment. While the tone of this still, ponderous, and tense gameplay style matches well with the story your patience will be what determines how much enjoyment you take from playing.

The music is well crafted and supports the ups and downs of the story. The acting, almost entirely a two hander, is literally 50/50 with some of the Northern Irish accents sounding loose and slipping from line to line.

I enjoyed the playthrough and I would recommend giving this story the time of day when available around €4 to €6 (or local equivalent). It's always good to play something that embraces challenging and new - to videogames - topics, even if not every aspect succeeds.
 
CHRONLINE

The graphics and landscape were indeed nice but just not enough to hold this game up to have any reason to come back for a replay. PS. the stage irish accents in the game were just terrible too almost cringeworthy

Recommandé
2.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 juillet 2018
It's interesting to play game that would popularly be called a "walking simulator" and have to talk about its survival and puzzle mechanics, since neither is particularly a part of the genre. Fidelio Incident places you on a frostbitten hellhole off Iceland in the wake of a plane crash. You struggle to dart from geothermal vents to flaming wreckage to stay warm while piecing together the mystery of what brought you and Leonore here in the first place.

Meanwhile Leonore, the love of your life, is freezing to death. You better hurry.

It's a strange sense of urgency for the genre and as things take a turn for the phantasmagorical, that urgency feels a little at odds with your trudging through underground complexes and circling the island opening new paths with new heat sources.

But the story, looking backward *and* forward, is interesting enough and the Fidelio Incident is certainly a pretty game -- one that lends to great screenshots. If you're in the market for some well-acted voice work, light puzzle solving, and a history lesson to boot, tied up in about two hours of game time, you can certainly do worse than this.

If anything deserves some real scorn, it's that the diary entry collection really fills out the story, but the achievement for finding them all doesn't come with a chapter select or count your pickups from previous runs. Nope. Prepare for multiple runs or a guide-assisted first try if you really want that 100%. That's a disappointing bit of extra work for a game that ought to be more willing to open its story to you.
 
it's shoe
0
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0

2.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 mai 2017
Produit reçu gratuitement

I rarely ever write reviews, but this game has to be one of the best indie games of 2017.

The game's story is captivating and the music surprisingly adds to that story.

It feels like every single element of the game is a puzzle piece that helps create that amazing bigger picture.

I highly recommend that everyone buys this game, it will take you around two hours to finish, but you'll end up talking about it with everyone long after.

Graphics: 9/10
Performance: 9/10 (Witnessed a couple performance hickups with my GTX1080 in 1080p)
Music: 10/10
Sound effects: 8/10
Story: 8/10

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Non recommandé
2.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 mars 2018
It's not bad, but it's a fairly weak walking sim compared to others in the past couple of yrs (Edith Finch, Firewatch and gone home). The story is disjointed and forced and it's unlikely you'll relate to the main character or his wife unlike in Firewatch for example (wanting to escape and being alone)... unless you're North Irish and somehow involved with the IRA. The gameplay is pretty dull and the puzzles feel unnecessary and contrived just so you have a challenge. But when three trees fall in your path in a row after you cleared a puzzle before each, it becomes beyond silly and just sloppy level design.

The love story that is at the core of the game is frankly irritating. I get you're trying to save your wife and all but both of them yammering how they miss and love each other gets annoying very quickly and you want to complete the mission just to get it over with. Other games approach the subject of romantic relationship much better (Gone home and Firewatch are two excellent examples) where you'll be rooting for the characters. In Fidelio, the chemistry just isn't there.

I do give points for the setting of a remote island near Iceland - gives a bit of a skyrim feel but more dangerous and deadly. I also give points for tackling the difficult subject of terrorism, especially Irish terrorism, which is scarcely talked about. Get it on sale for a few bucks - it's only 2-3h of play.
 
The Dainty Cossack
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
9.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 décembre 2018
Inspired by Beethoven's only opera, as also suggested by its title, The Fidelio Incident recounts a plane accident that ends up separating a young couple, Stanley and Leonore, in a vast snow-covered landscape littered with half-dead jellyfish and giant animal skeletons. During a desperate search for his beloved wife, Stanley's apparently lost memories gradually resurface, painting a not so rosy picture of his past...

From fragments of Leonore's diary that he discovers among the plane's burnt ruins and in a hostile environment where his greatest enemies are the cold and himself, Stanley and the players are informed of a crucial dilemma he has had to deal with, imposed upon him by a person who had the power to blackmail him. With explicit allusions to Ireland's recent history, The Fidelio Incident is not, however, a politically oriented game - rather philosophically inclined, it mainly explores the psychology and motives of someone caught in a tragic battle between two faiths; in other words, between his ideology and his heart.

Although the graphics and general feel of the game remind strongly of Dear Esther and Kholat, the plot is interestingly diversified, leading us to the final twist through a brilliantly assembled barrage of surreal/nightmarish sequences. Quite meaty for its brevity, with a beautiful soundtrack by classical pianist and composer Michael Krikorian, The Fidelio Incident offers about two hours of agonized existential quest that will satisfy most fans of the genre.

And there's nothing to explore really anyway. The game is very linear, without choices and the puzzles aren't very interesting.

Think of it like an Unreal Engine 4 demo.

Okey, do you have to play it? If you like good classical/jazzy music, great voice acting and pretty graphics, and dont mind a bad plot with plenty of holes, cheap plot devices and tedious gameplay, go for it.

1.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 mai 2017
Had a terrible time getting controls to work at first, had to screw around with screen resolution a lot. Mouse sensitivity jacked up all the way and it still ended up making my arm hurt from all the excess movement just looking around.

Story doesn't have much of an impact on me, as it relies on you caring about the characters from the start, which I definitely don't. Also, tries to build up to a 'big reveal' but instead it feels like an obvious and far too drawn-out conclusion.

Might be a bit more impactful if I had any notion of Irish politics, too. It doesn't seem like Stanley had a very strong motivation for his actions, so it mostly left me confused.

Puzzles were entertaining, visuals are pretty good. Voice acting is nice, but the intermittent soliloquys felt ridiculous.

This is a walking sim with some very high production value on all fronts. The graphics are stunning, the voice acting is spectacular. They were so easy, that they felt entirely uneccesary and just bogged down the game. The story and atmosphere are the good parts! Either add good puzzles, or leave 'em out. Overall though, I do highly recommend this experience!

Évaluation publiée le 7 février 2019
On the one hand it felt like I experienced most of this in a more profound, lyrical and idyllic way in "Dear Esther" years ago, on the other hand this is a visually stunning game without a doubt and the little puzzles did enhance the experience to some degree. While the voiceacting did convince me, the story doesn't really develop any further from a certain point on and one can really guess where things are going to. The soundtrack is decent, the length fitting and the sheer vastness, hostility and twisted beauty of the landscapes never fails to impress, but apart from a gripping atmosphere and hopelessness, there is little to remember once the credits roll and the game feels the need to make it abundantly clear what just happened. Still a beautiful game, tense at times and definitely enjoyable....once. 7,5/10

459 produits enregistrés

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
2.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 février 2022
Great walking simulator with a nice atmosphere and graphics - 7.5/10

Really enjoyable experience, you play a man searching for his wife after a plane crash. You walk around, use levers to solve little puzzles and pick up pages from your wifes journal to learn more about the protaganists past.
Gameplay wise you don't have to do a lot, but with games like this, the story and athmosphere is very important, and they nailed it in this game. The game looks awesome and really makes you feel like you are there, nice soundtrack as well.

In the beginning you always have to look out for fire or warm air coming out of the ground to not freeze, that hindererd the exploration a bit for me, would have liked it more if the time before you freeze would be a bit longer.

Give it a shot if you like walking sims with a nice story like The Vanishing of Ethan Carter.


100%-Achievement-Difficulty: Very easy, find all journal pages, everything else will come with story progress.

Check out my curator if you liked this review: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42987949/
 
TheLeon1897
1,318 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 aout 2017
The Fidelio Project is a small gem in the rough (2 hours long). Don't be misled by its harsh setting. Unlike The Long Dark, this game is not focused on surviving, but rather travelling through a mysterious world in search of your wife. Where many games over rely on optional diary entries to provide depth of story, The Fidelio Incident gives context through many mandatory pages which are well voiced acted and scattered out of chronological order. This revitalises what could be dry collectibles and keeps the player guessing how seemingly disconnected events led to one another. Even though it is only loosely based upon Bethoven’s source material, its contemporary twist is more relevant and still conveys the key themes of the opera. 4/5
 
SirEarlGrey
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 juillet 2018
Been a gamer longer than many people on Steam have been alive. Played a lot of adventure games. This is the first to reference The Troubles in a major way. I'd love to see more, as it was such a big part of my country's history, but that's up to game devs.

The game itself is beautiful in that way that games based in desolate wastelands can be. See also such great island-based walking simulators like Dear Esther and Montague's Mount. I was drawn to it primarily because it was on sale... but also because I love story rich adventure, walking simulators, and Irish protagonists.

The story is great and heart-rending at times. Won't say to much more because; spoilers, but it's opened up by journal entries (trope alert, but not a tacky one), dream sequences (trope alert, yes. Dream sequences, but it's ok) and the occasional phone call.

The music is beautiful (and available as a free DLC).

The puzzles aren't particularly challenging; see a blockage, turn a leaver, blockage gone. Possibly a more challenging puzzle approach would separate the user from the narrative, which was the main part of the game. Having to trek back and forth for hours, figuring out what you need to do to get past an obstacal is probably better suited to a game where the plot doesn't keep reminding you that your wife is dying of hypothermia.

The voice acting is... well... not the best. This is my major gripe with an otherwise fantastic experience. Glenn Keogh who plays Stanley is fine, however his peotic monologues popping up between his frostbite induced swearing seemed out of place and could have been presented better. Not his fault. Other than this his frustration with his situation comes across as authentic. However Bess Harrison's (Leonore) vague "Oirish" accent was all over the shop. It was especially off-putting as she was supposedly from the north, and as someone from the north I couldn't recognise it. It sounded like Cork, with a bit of Derry filtered through Darby O'Gill. It was especially jarring when we heard her father in flashback who has a recognisable northern accent. I know actors from the north of Ireland, so such a creature does exist. They have agents and everything. I'm not sure why Act3 felt they needed to hire someone to fake it badly. It probably doesn't upset anyone who isn't from Ireland but to a native, the awkward pronounciations and lack of a distinct regional accent took me out of the game somewhat.

My own minor cultural quibbles aside I thought this was one of the best short adventure games I've played since Dear Esther. I got it quite cheaply but it's worth the full asking price which isn't much. If you rush it, which you shouldn't, you can complete it in the time it takes to watch a Zach Snyder film. Which you won't enjoy as much.
 
PRAEst76
731 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 septembre 2017
A mystery walking simulator with good voice acting, beautiful graphics, an enriching soundtrack and an enthralling story.

Stanley, the character you play as, gets in a plane crash while flying over an island, with a few minor puzzles along the way you must find your missing wife, who was on the plane with you when it crashed.
Along the way you find pieces of her diary which you collect to solve pieces of the puzzle, and find out more about Stanley and Leonore's life.

There isn't much interactivity from the player in this walking simulator aside from the linear puzzles.

It's not on the top of the list of walking simulators, but it's far from the bottom of the list.
It manages to capture you throughout the game and the story that's being told keeps you going. There are slow parts, but there's thrilling and fast paced parts as well.

The voice acting was good, as I already said, but it was not the greatest. It feels as if the VO artists overact a few times.

Saying more than that will spoil story or gameplay that you should experience for yourself, so I'll stop here.

Buy it if you're into walking simulators and want a 2-hour long mystery adventure with some minor puzzles, a great soundtrack, and a story that keeps you going.

If you liked this review or otherwise found it helpful in deciding whether or not to buy this game, feel free to follow my Curator page.

1,239 produits enregistrés

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
0.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 avril 2018
I really wanted to like this game - it's indie, it has a reputation for a great story, it was recommended for people who liked Firewatch... but I encountered a lot of problems. In the 15 minutes I played.

First of all, this seems almost specifically designed to make motion sickness work. Head bob? Check. Disorienting turns with motion blur? Check. Inability to change FOV? Check. I got sick even in the short time I tried it. Adjusting the X and Y settings for "look" didn't seem to make any difference, even when I put them as low as possible - a mere breath of wind on the mouse resulted in a disorienting jerk of camera movement.

Second of all, I had technical issues - in the 15 minutes I tried it, it froze three times. And that's after I set it to the lowest possible graphics settings.

Third, the part about finding diary entries is just silly (this is not a spoiler, it starts immediately). You're in a plane crash, and everything's on fire, but somehow the diary entries survived and just scattered. Even if it is a metaphor, that's still ridiculous and distracting.

I ended up asking for a refund on this one.

Not a massively long game. Lasted about 2 hours. Its a walking simulator with pretty linear game play. The freezing mechanics does not allow much opportunity to explore the surrounding. The puzzles are very simple. Story is mainly uncovered through the journal pages littered around the map. Felt that the sound track was the only thing worth the money in this game. All in all an okay game with little narrative.

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 novembre 2019
The graphics are nice, and feel cold, but the gamification of hypothermia doesn't work for me.

Run for 20 seconds in arctic winds: you die. Run for 19 seconds in arctic winds: you live. Now please run for several minutes between conveniently placed heat sources, but do them in the right order and don't go exploring, because if any segment is more than 20 seconds, you'll die. Also you can swim through arctic water for ages without a problem, but if you fall into the same water while crossing ice floes then you're dead. The game's invisible rules don't make any believeable sense.

And talking of believability, I don't think any of authors have ever visited Northern Ireland. If they had, The Troubles would not be a convenient source of plot.
 
Kyzer

Évaluation publiée le 13 mai 2019
When I started playing it, i felt it was like a walking simulator version of The Long Dark. As I kept playing, the sheen wore off and it became a chore to finish it. I became acutely aware of all the beats it was going to hit and then, yeah it did that thing.
There was a specific moment towards the end that annoyed me greatly where the PC says a thing, then you IMMEDIATELY see a sign which directly tells you what it all means.
This is not a game that goes in for subtlety. The voice acting is not the best, the puzzle design is uninspired, but its very very very pretty.
It's not a great walking simulator, but its on the high end of bad.

Évaluation publiée le 10 aout 2017
Had a good time with this game and finished it in about 3 hours. The story was good enough that I wanted to finish it and the music and voice acting were great as were the visuals - near photo realistic.

Pros:
-Visuals: breathtaking views and changing weather.
-Voice acting was very convincing and the actors really sold their dialogue.
-Story was good, but not great.
-Music: the music set the tone for how you are to feel during the game and especially toward the end it really ramped up.

♥♥♥♥:
-No sprint: Not being able to sprint made a journey across the map feel very long and uninteresting at times.
-Story: Some of what was told you on the pages of the diary I couldn't have cared less about.
-Switches: most of the puzzles were find switch, pull lever and turn handle over and over like 50 times. Could have used a bit more variety.

Évaluation publiée le 16 mars 2020
I do not recommend this game, even for free. It's incredibly dull and the boredom is excruciating. I can appreciate what the developers were going for, but the plot "twist" was so forced and could be seen way ahead of time. The puzzles are easy and unsatisfying. The voice acting was decent but the dialogue was written poorly. The visuals were extremely grainy.

I don't mean to be so harsh as I think it's apparent that the developer put in a lot of work to do this and I will admit that the game at least is a full experience with little hiccups. It's just one of those games that, as a completionist, I felt compelled to finish it although I just couldn't wait for it to be over.
 
nessiehaze
767 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
9.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 juillet 2018
For a dollar on the Steam summer sale it's not a bad buy. Ultimately I found the story to be rather predictable. particularly because of how the "journal" is conveniently spread around and you have to collect pages to push the narrative (though I wish you wouldn't have to stand there in place to read each page, but you could collect it an audio narrative would play as you keep walking).

It's a pretty game. Solid effort on the graphics and the game starts off a decent survival mystery.

But, what can I say? The puzzles, the locale, everything just makes zero sense from a logical standpoint that the surprise is not so much a surprise.

I would surely recommend it to anyone for a dollar though.

+ Good controls

+ Not much to keep you entertained

3.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 décembre 2022
If you like walking sims this is 100% what you're looking for.

It's a short game - about 2 hours, 2 1/2. But it's the right length for the story it's telling. Let the length tell you if you should wait for a sale or not. It's the classic walk around and hear an emotional story. It doesn't reinvent the wheel but it's a really good, solid wheel. It deals with some mature themes, so it's not a pick me up on a sad day kind of game. But good for I am in my feels and I want to stay there. Very pretty, great sound design. There's some puzzles but I was never really lost or stuck.

You almost feel like you are playing Lost but on a frozen Island rather than a Tropical one! Excellent graphics however one issue is the game is short. As you can see I have completed it in just under 3 hours and that's including having the game minimised for around 30-40 minutes of that time. So good game but very short.
 
Jay30mcr
144 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 juin 2017
Finished the game...just: brilliant.
What a GREAT story. Heartbreaking,actually. Interesting puzzles and environment interactions. Rich musical score. Gorgeous scenery:from mountains to blizzards, to a burning forest, to "dream sequences", fire and water and ice effects, all rendered beautifully.
From the opening scene: the tension of being in a doomed plane, through the final heartbreaking scene (no spoilers), the pace is SO much more than a "walking simulator". Am I going to freeze to death? Rescue my woman in time?
I didn't at all mind taking time from the journey to stop and collect diary pages (progressing the backstory in such a way that you weren't taken out of the game's "reality").
OK, not really a spoiler but: the pub. Jesus; I wanted to stay there for a while. EVERY environment so hyper-realistic within the context of a "bad dream" (no spoiler THERE, I didn't say it WAS a dream; just how the game looks at times).
Worth $10 on Steam? Actually, worth MORE...for what I got out of the game and from it.
My only two "negatives" and they're minor:
-As noted here, the game has issues playing on max 1920X1080 rez screens. I dropped my rez down a notch to 1680X1050 and the game played great after that point.
-I'd give anything for there to have been save-at-will points, so I could revisit areas in the game (even if it's to marvel at the scenery; it's all really that great-looking). I realize there must be issues with programmers creating options for save slots or else why would so many DEVs leave that option out, and this game does auto-save in many areas. But I'd love for there to have been an option besides CONTINUE. I want to re-play certain areas, and not the game again from scratch, when I've finished the game.
That's it. This game is SO worth the money, and it's so difficult to believe a game like this was developed with such a small (but obviously talented) team. Make more games,MaverickWolf!
Well done.
