Évaluation publiée le 26 février 2018
As far as Walking Simulators go, this game is very much just a standard experience.

While it does feature some beautiful venues and the story manages to hold your interest, (even though you can guess the ending relatively early).

The game is not too long, I completed it in 90 minutes and even though it's not too long I think the last and second to last part of the game managed to drag on for a bit and made me lose interest.

It's worth picking this game up on a sale, but I would advice against buying it at full price.
For 3€ it's a worth while experience, after all, it's cheaper than a pint at the bar.

It is absolutely worth the purchase. I fully enjoyed it.

I hadn't heard of this game before seeing it on Steam, so I didn't have much in the way of expectations going in. Upon playing and completing the game, I can say that I thoroughly enjoyed it, even though I could see where the story was going, almost from the beginning.

Due to the extreme short-length, I wouldn't recommend this game at full-price, but for $2-3, it's worth every penny. It's a shame walking simulators like Firewatch get so much public coverage, when they aren't half as intriquing, or half the game Fidelio is.

Produit reçu gratuitement

Produit remboursé

The idea behind the game is really great, and the game itself has a great story. For 10 euros I wouldn't expect that much more, but sadly I missed the whole concept of the game. Not because I didn't know where to go, but because I kept going places too soon. I found the plane door which is used as a shield to block the large, snowy rocks, before knowing what to use it for, and later on in the bunker I found and used a handle before knowing what it did. That's also where i quit. Because of this, I wouldn't recommend spending 10 euros on this.

Évaluation publiée le 8 février 2018
The game is easy, you only have to walk to your objectives, click a few things, and overcome some obstacles. The game is beautiful even though sometimes it might seem blurry (I'm presuming it's because he is freezing to death and he is trying to stay focus). The music with it is fantastic and goes well with the game. You play as Stanley trying to go save your wife leanore, while looking for all of her lost journal pages. I won't get into anything more about the game. It's worth the $3 right now on sale. I would even pay full price for it even though the game was really short. It is definitely replayable to try to get all the journal pages if you were not able to get them all the first try.

Your plane crashes and you need to get to another section of the plane. As you traverse the wilderness, survive the cold with fire and steam vents, you pick up journal pages that tell the story. The game itself is rather short.

Pros:
  • Beautiful world
  • Interesting story
  • Decent puzzle elements

    ♥♥♥♥
  • Very short

Évaluation publiée le 28 janvier 2018
A very short, narrative driven walking sim, similar to games like Firewatch. Total playtime was less than two hours; so if you think $10 is a little steep just wait for a sale like I did.

Overall the game felt average; the story was interesting but I had most of it figured out after just a few minutes of playing. The graphics are pretty standard UE4 visuals that keep you engaged, and the music score is probably the best thing about the game.

A very short, average game with decent visuals and good soundtrack. Not a bad game, but nothing mindblowing either.
6/10

2.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 janvier 2018
A fun little walking sim to sit and finish in an afternoon. Nice soundtrack, although I did hit a couple of times where the sound seemed to stop but reloading the game solved that.

Some minor puzzle solving (how do I get from here to there?) Along with a failure state which returns you to the last checkpoint if you stay in the cold too long.

The story was interesting and once I started to piece it together made me want to keep playing to see how it ended. I didn't find all of the journal pages on my first playthrough, although I feel like I must've found "most", so will want to go back again to see if that makes any major difference.

3.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 janvier 2018
It's an exceptional, mature story told in the shape of part real, part surreal, part halucinogenic first person experience with some searching and puzzles to break the tempo.
The only problem is the fact that the game sometimes fails to start or to trigger the next sequence. Restarting may be required. At one point I even thought the game was legitimately over (and it seemed like an ingenious ending too!), just to restart for fun and to find out it was anything but. Actually, maybe it was over, because I didn't do the thing I was supposed to do at that point, which I did on the restart, who knows... BTW, the real ending didn't trigger at all, had to watch it on YouTube. If i wasn't for that, I'd put it next to Vanishing of Ethan Carter - not so unbelievably lavish and creative (well ahead of its time), but somewhat better story, imho. Games like Dear Esther or Cradle don't even come close. Firewatch is comparable, imho, but Fidelio's much, much shorter and without any backtracking. Haven't played Edith Finch yet, though, it's gonna be next :)
 
debe.sys
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 décembre 2017
A great walking simulator with an excellent story well told. Unfortunately, as the development studio are from the USA there is a fair amount of fiddle-dee-dee-isation going on. The voice acting, while competently done, was wholly unsuitable for people who are supposed to be from Belfast. And there are other representations of life in the north of the island which are predictably twee. Regardless, it's still a well told story. And the gameplay is solid as well, as there's a fair amount of interaction to keep the walking simulator experience from growing stale. At first it has you running from heat source to heat source to stave off hypothermia, and then you're redirecting steam to clear off swarming insects or put out fires, or draining pools to open up new areas. Short and sweet, with the whole thing wrapping up in 2 hours. But it doesn't outstay it's welcome, and for the price on sale it's very worth it.

Very short but fun to play. There is very little challenge. You just have to find a route past obstacles which is mostly obvious but sometimes requires a bit of backtracking and trial and error turning valves. The logic of the puzzles doesn't really work but they keep up the tension and the unfolding background story is good. Unlike a lot of games, it is well worth picking up the scattered sheets and reading them. I stayed interested throughout the two and a half hours it took me to complete. If it had been longer I would have become bored. Overall it just scrapes a thumbs up.

Recommandé
2.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 octobre 2017
Fidelio Incident is walking simulator narrating story thru diary entries and halucinations.

Gameplay-wise there is not mutch to talk about, you walk between warm places (burning wreckage and steam geysers), read diary scattered all over the frozen island and sometimes you click valve to make more steam.

Grafic is pretty, music is OK and voice acting is well done.

Most important aspect is the story you explore thru diary and hallucinations. Its story about lovers on background of north irish terrorism and it was pretty good.

My only complain is lengh. I completed this game in 2,2 hours (according to steam). If i didnt eat lunch in middle of playing i could finish it and still ask for refund .... thats way too short in my opinion
 
🅹🅸🆂🅺🆁🅰
2,040 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 octobre 2017
Fidelio Incident is a brief and, for narrative game enthusiasts, interesting title. Set in the an unspecified Icelandic landscape in the early 2000s, the game features two characters, Stanley and Leanore - an Irish couple whose convoluted history unfolds throughout the game.

In many ways, Fidelio Incident is actually a reverse Firewatch. Set in the a harsh winter landscape, fraught with hazards, guilt trips and downright nervous breakdowns, Fidelio is set in a more emotionally turbulent scale than the easy-going nature of Firewtach. For those unfamiliar with the backstory of recent Irish history, a quick Wikipedia search on the Troubles in Northern Ireland may also prove useful, as the plot may appear a bit alien.

Gameplay is simple and it's based on a non-HUD interface, where elemental effects (cold, fire or such things are signified via representations around the edges of the screen (cold creates frost, fire emits flames et cetera). There are no mobile threats like wildlife as in similar survival type games, allowing for a more leisurely pace and awareness.

Fidelio Incident takes about 2-3 hours to complete - not particularly long, and certain parts do feel a bit like rubber-necking. One can go into specific details about its narrative, which could definitely be improved but overall it delivers its promise and concludes its story with a decent twist.
 
MarkedAsRed
393 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 octobre 2017
What can I say about The Fidelio Incident, was an excellent playthrough, however like many of the other reviews of the game, its very much in the style of a walking simulator. However that is not all there is to the game, there are puzzles you have to solve also, so it does keep you on your toes. My biggest complaint about The Fidelio Incident is the game is fairly short, if I could compare it to another game that is simular in the gameplay style, it would definitely be Firewatch, game play and story mode definitely give you a vested interest in the main characters. But it seemed rushed abit, and moved quickly, from one area to the other. But at the same time, kept a decent pace also. I livestreamed this game for my community, and the reviews are great! But they seemed to think it was more like a movie, based on pacing ect... But all in all it is a great game! If I could give this a rating I would give it 9 out of 10 stars, the only reason for it loosing a star is just in shortness of the game, and also the fact I do not see it as a replayable game, but I might go back to get all of the journal.

167 produits enregistrés

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 septembre 2017
Produit reçu gratuitement

I went into the experience excited for a beautiful story rich game... and wasn't disappointed. The Fidelio Incident is a beautiful slow paced experience revolving around a man's search for his wife. The environments are beautiful and the soundtrack sets the mood perfectly. The experience itself is extremely linear though, with not too much to explore outside of simple progression. That doesn't necessarily feel out of place here though, because the barriers keeping you on your path are, for the most part, sensible (other than the army of beautiful jelly fish, the flash freezing water, and the swarms of insects) . The story, for me, started off kind of confusing and slow. As the game progressed, the story began to reveal itself and the payoff was well worth the time I invested. Is this the best story rich game I have ever played? No. Is it worth the investment of your time and money? I think so.
 
ValkyrieSix
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 septembre 2017
A competent entry in the walking-sim subgenre, most notable for its superb imagery and emotional content. The puzzles are straightforward and reasonable, if a bit repetitive here and there. The subject matter is an unusual choice from recent history that is both bold and respectful. I found the voice acting to be excellent, which isn't always the case in games developed by small shops.

The overall play is a bit short and the puzzles could have been more challenging. Moreover, the puzzles seem a bit absurd here and there. There's a reason for that, but it comes out late in the game and, until you learn what it is, you may find the absurdity distracting.

If you liked Firewatch but prefer a richer graphic context, more akin to The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, have a look at this one. Where Firewatch held fast to a rigid realism, The Fidelio Incident might remind you here and there of the "Twin Peaks" TV show. Now, Firewatch, Carter, and "Twin Peaks" all got an "A" from me, while this one earns a respectable "B." If you like walking sims, great imagery, and the enigmatically surreal, that's a "B" you should try yourself.
 
steve
152 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 septembre 2017
What a beautiful game! The graphics are doing their job really well (even on the lowest settings) and give the game scenery it's agressive and scary beauty.
The plot is nothing spectacular in it self but has some nice twists and turns throughout the entire storyline. I do not want to spoil anything but do play through the entire game in one session if possible (I did it in 2.5h but I'm sure it can be done in less) to get the whole picture. Although it is a shame that the story is entierly linear...

Sadly I found the music/audio to be somewhat lacking, which is sad for a game that is marketing itself on being inspired by Beethoven's only opera. The soundtrack in itself is good, no question about it, but the occasional mixing and layering of different soundtracks (on purpose or not...) made me feel somewhat lost. Aswell as the game lacking some clear audio effects:
- No footstep or splash sound when walking in water
- Mostly the same footstep sound no matter if walking on dirt or snow
- Some interactibles lacked sound effects which made them feel "hollow" and without weight

Control wise the game clearly is made to be played with a controller and not with mouse and keyboard (although it is possible). Especially noticable is this when the cursor randomly dissapears from the menu or the camera goes into som kind of "hold-and-drag" mode. Another thing that annoyed me was the fact that I as the player never got any control over when I wanted my flash light to be on or off. I understand that there are some points in the game where the player should not get access to something that makes seeing easier but there are better solutions to that than taking the decision entierly away from the player.

My last little nit-picky-critic-point is the lack of some kind of inventory symbols. Although there was no need to know what you had at your disposal (because of the game always using the right tool for you), it would have been nice to have some kind of icon reminding you: "Hey you got this flash light back there, why don't you use it to get through this dark cave?"

Overall I do recommend the game to anyone who likes games like Firewatch or any other pussel adventure with a bit of horror mixed into it, especially if it is on sale!

I hope this was helpfull :)
Frokes
 
frokes the SWE/GER

Recommandé
4.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 septembre 2017
I enjoy walking simulators because they are relaxing and let you do something when not in the mood for a more demanding game. The Fidelio Incident actually gives the player some incentive to keep moving, however, making this more of a "run or you're going to freeze to death" simulator.

The graphics are pretty and the voice actors did a wonderful job bringing the character's emotions out. My only real complaint is a glitch I exprienced near the end. Running down a long hallway to reach the final value my screen goes white after Stanley falls, from there the game freezes. Took 4 or 5 tries to get beyond it (all I did was continue to press forward and the action button). Don't know if that is what saved me, but not going to question it.

Had to replay the game to collect the journal pages I missed. Otherwise, it was a good experience overall. Game is a bit short, though I can't really give you numbers on that. Maybe about 2 hours, less if you aren't collecting everything.
 
WingxofxRuin

Recommandé
2.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 aout 2017
A quick well made game, but one I wouldn't want to replay.
Excellent story and voice acting, but you only need to hear it once. Which means you're paying for a one-off play of 2-3 hours. Simple 'puzzles' which usually involve turning valves and flippling levers.
Not open world - walking on rails. Not able to jump (which actually in retrospect seems OK but at the time of playing seems silly). Good graphics but only very occassionally something special to stop and look at.
I was quite glad when I'd finished it as it got more frustrating than enjoyable towards the end.
I'm going to recommend it because overall I enjoyed being part of the story.

Évaluation publiée le 29 juillet 2017
This game blew me away. The story is beautifully written, the scenery is gorgeous.

It was shorter than I hoped it would be, but I feel it was well worth the price. It's up there with Firewatch for sure.

I can't wait for more games from Act3.

Welcome to my blind playthrough of The Fidelio Incident, a survival game about trying to escape the cold, and your past. Part One, surviving a plane crash and taking stock of the area.

Non recommandé
0.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 septembre 2017
I ran into a bug, so something is "botched" with it, so I watched the whole game-playthrough online - TLDR: I felt the story was quite "colorless". Definitely a "Walking Simulator" however the "Adventure"-part is quite lacking.

An Alternative, "artsy"-way, of encapsulating: It simply lacks the "fidelidi-fidelido" spirit of Beethoven's Opera! :(


The story is about a couple of macks and the setting is a sort of small-sized (or "mediocre" at best), unstable and bug-infested, island close to Iceland (I'm Icelandic which is why I bought into this game in the 1st. place).

The player's character is having flashbacks about his mate's bastard father (among few other tidbits - of which there shall be little mention in this review). The final-point is: It's a sob-story about the hero questing to gain pure, and cold, insight into past shame.

Not a jolly good game but, really, neither fantastic nor speculative (imo. a sort of "small-minded" story-loom - lacks a bit more "boombast" to be memorable). Just rather "effectless" and "affectless". On the positive it has some atmosphere, a somewhat cool background environment, and certain "whoop-de-doo" moments.

Overall, the story was short and its dynamism slow-motion. Uneventful, a real sleeper, with dysmal undercurrent: the boring tinge of banalism. Sort of tasteless, with little meat on the bones.

(Btw. For some, quite strange, reason I just didn't feel weepy at the end.)

Pretty good value for the money. There is a story to be told here and it's told fairly well. The puzzles are simplistic but they aren't what the story is really about and most likely only there as padding. It's at the right price point and if you enjoy a walking sim then this is for you.

it's quite short, I completed it in 2 hours with no help or cheat. I wouldn't say it is the best walking simulator I've done so far. I enjoyed more Firewatch. This one goes crazy at times when Stanley has hallucinations. The prison bit took too long, was too pointless. And the bit of the stairs, what's the point of making me go up and up and up for nothing?

I did not like the ending either. The game seems rather repetitive for a walking simulator, I expected more scenery, much better views, it felt lacking.

It's the perfect way to kick back and relax after a day at work, I played it in bursts over about a week and always looked forward to going back to Stanley's world.

Recommandé
2.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 juin 2017
This game was visually incredible, though some elements of the animations could have been a bit more polished; for example, the "hand presence" (seeing your hands in the game) was a little bit clunky, could have been smoother.

The voice acting was top notch, very engaging, though as some have stated, there are moments where the main character switches from actively commenting on his surroundings to some sort of internal dialouge. It feels deep and mysterious, but also a little out of place, though not excessively so for me.

I did not realize how short it was going into it, so I was actually expecting a bit more. I would say "visually" it was worth the price I paid ($15), but gameplay and length-wise it was not. For a "walking-simulator" it has some interactive gameplay and "puzzle" elements, but the same mechanics end up being used throughout which gets a bit old even despite the very short length (less than 2 hours).

The story was quite emotional and really socks you in the gut at the end; you feel both devastated but also a little proud of the main character's final accomplishment

The music was excellent and fit the game very well.
 
JQ
2
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 juin 2017
The Fidelio Incident delivers a poignant personal story told through the charming accents of a mysterious Irish couple, stranded and separated, with a dark secret to hide.

The game is not as sinister or paranormal as Kholat, but otherwise comparable in many ways, letting you explore massively inhospitable environments through impressively realistic wintry visuals and sounds.

Here, the experience feels less solitary as the main character occasionally receives one-way communications from his unreachable wife, but its story is also mostly delivered through collected bits of evenly scattered diaries and sporadic soliloquy.

Fidelio is also entirely about hypothermia, as the more than revealing signs inform you early on and every step of the way. You have to stay warm, so you'll walk quickly from fire to fire and other occasional heat sources, where the landscape and plot both progressively turn into a surreal guilt trip.

The few items you need are always conveniently located within an easily accessible short range, so there isn't really any reason to divert much from the clear path. Pipes and switches will bring a series of elementary puzzles to solve in order to stay warm or avoid stingy bugs. This is a thoroughly well executed interactive narrative that nevertheless brings absolutely nothing new to the genre's gameplay formula.

It helps to optionally have a basic understanding of Ireland's 1980's political landscape, as the game's underlining setting. Offers around 2-3 hours of icy exploration, a fitting length for a story without filler that doesn't need to be any longer.
 
ElusiveOne

3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 mai 2017
Very interesting setting, the music set the mood well keeping me on edge throughout.

Nice touch with the notes which helped give some insight to the given situation.

The puzzles were good but they were all too similar to each other. Also, the ending was a bit of a let-down as it felt unsatisfying to me.

But overall very entertaining and the length of the play felt just right.

7/10

3.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 mai 2017
Pros:

- Beautiful visuals
- Top notch voice acting
- A different type of story involving dark subject material
- Excellent pacing

♥♥♥♥:
- Simple puzzles involving steam valves
- Very straight forward walking simulator
- Short game lasting around 3 hours

If you're a fan of "Firewatch" or "The Vanishing of Ethan Carter", you will really enjoy this game.
